It's light, has egg white and is totally discontinued and will not be made again as told to us by our server. Apparently our table ordered the very last one in existence since they will no longer be making this drink anymore at Beretta. Plenty of extinct hummingbird jokes followed our courses. The risotto was incredible, we had a person with celiac's and we had to ensure it was gluten-free which they are (thankfully) and the peas infused risotto was perfectly flavored, like eating somebody's mom's cooking (definitely not my mom, she's Asian and risotto would be porridge). The squid ink one was quite adventurous looking since it came out black but was quite tasty and intensely flavored, not like the nasty seafood taste, but a more refined dark and tangy flavor that went well with my mixed drink, the vulture from the bird cocktail menu.Such a great experience dining here and the ambiance is great. The open kitchen is bustling and the folks are accommodating here (sat me down early and got me a table even though I had no reservation). This place is insanely busy- always packed and every table filled up on our Thursday night. I will definitely be coming back here again, this place was a joy.

Awesome place. I had been going to Westlake Joe's in Daly City my entire life and loved the place. Went to Original Joe's for the first time recently and enjoyed the food and ambiance greatly. Had the Cheeseburger and side of ravioli's. Everything tasted great and the only downside was service was slow.

So I picked this Italian restaurant for lunch one fine cool crisp day because it had decent reviews...And most restaurants you find through Yelp in San Francisco are usually spot on.Usually.. very rarely.. do you get a bad seed. Most restaurants here are all amazing with superb service..This one..hmmm how shall I put it not so much.. a bad seed. •_ I ordered the Panzanello Salad with chicken: diced heirloom tomatoes, English cucumber, red onion, toasted fennel croutons, red wine vinegar, evoo.And I what got was raw chicken under cooked... Ahh the horror.. Who eats raw chicken?When I explained to the waitress about my under cooked chicken, she responded" oh that's how the chicken is cooked" Hmmm. No that's not how I cook my chicken... no pink and when you cut it open you can see the silky membranes still attached to the chicken. that to me is undercooked. And what happend to the customer is always right? The server was not accomodating nor was she friendly about it. After sitting there not touching it, she comes back after 20 mintues. No customer service skills. Why didn't you get the manager or apologized and tried to get me something else and not say do you want to take it to go? Yeah, and actually cook it in my kitchen.. Thanks but no thanks..And my fiance had the smoked proscuitto panini that was ham..ham like sandwich ham..Stay clear of this one my friends... •_you will get sick..!

I was in the mood for some good ol' chinese food. Being new to the area, we weren't sure where the heck to order from for delivery. We searched google, and sorta grub hub, and randomly selected this place.Pretty awesome.On our menu:Won Ton SoupVeggie Chow FunChicken
ar|
im Sum Restaurant|

You don't often think of heading to the Outer Richmond for food. For both Aziza and Pizzetta 211 it's worth the trip. Their pizzas change often with fresh and in season ingredients. The crust is perfectly baked. The food is fairly simple in the best kind of way-- no molecular gastronomy, just good old fashioned really high quality ingredients prepared in a way that showcases them. I live in the Mission so don't get out here as often as I'd like to, but highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't been.

We came here after lunch at La Taqueria in the Mission •_for a big snack of chicken soup, broccoli rabe, and collard greens. •_First of all, we never got water so I had to get my table water. •_After that, the waiter who wore a kitty shirt (shirt covered in kitty heads) told us that there was no such thing as broccoli rabe on the menu (even though broccoli rabe was clearly written on their white board!) after we ordered the collard greens and liked it. •_He asked the kitchen and said he was wrong and then placed an order for us. •_Both greens were actually overly salted but the chicken soup was tasty. •_Service was underwhelming and actually incompetent. •_Their breadsticks were laying against a dirty wall at our tiny table. •_This particular location is so small that it felt like we were sardines inside a can. After their opening hours started, they continued to slowly take their time to place settings on the tables while a group of people waited outside in bad weather. •_Not recommended.

Pretty much everything you could want in an Italian restaurant. The staff is very friendly and entertaining to interact with as well as knowledgeable about the food they serve - which is great for the price and the atmosphere is lively and infectious.Not a quiet place for a first date but a true dining experience and some drinks and good food with friends or a fun dinner before a night out.

Food was very good. Dejah the waitress was very good. The Giant stuffed rigatoni with sausage wAs awesome. The bar waitress Angela was very rude when a member of my party asked her a question otherwise it's a 5.

This was a great spot for Mexican comfort food. We got the quesadilla with pork belly and it was great! Crunchy exterior, and lots of meat and cheese inside. Big enough for a meal or a good appetizer for two. We also got the trout at the recommendation of our waitress. It comes on a bed of beans and a broth that was delicious. The tortillas it comes with are handmade -- I watched them make it behind the counter pretty much all night. We also tried a variety of mezcals from their extensive selection. I also had a white sangria which was a little sweet in my opinion but I liked the basil finish. I would come back here to try more of their dishes. It's also on a great street with cute shops and right next to Golden Gate Park.

Possible some of the best red and green salsa in town. •_These folks are always sooooo nice and sweet, if you can bust out the spanish you are in for life. •_I love the suizas w/ carne asada. •_The whole pinto beans are superior as are the burritos. •_I am a traditionalist. •_Skip all the lettuce and frills, go for meat bean and some chesse maybe salsa inside too, but that's all. •_I will drive all the way across town to go there when the craving kicks in.

So bad it's almost funny. Ordered vegetarian pot sticker they brought ground pork. Ordered soup dumplings, they brought ground pork. Ordered Spicy bok choy they brought cold Napa cabbage, not spicy. Pork buns were really good. Worst part, the steam baskets were really dirty. Couldn't leave fast enough.
Delicious Azada tacos! awesome with their hot sauce only wish they served alcohol!

Oh, Eric, I'm so disappointed. I've heard such wonderful things about your Chinese food in the past couple of months. Finally decided to try it for myself. Now, I did appreciate that my sesame chicken, pork and green beans and wonton soup was ready in 5 minutes -- kudos to you on that. And I'd overlook that I asked for two helpings of rice and one soup, not two soups and one rice. No biggie. It's Saturday night, and I'm sure you're busy. But the fact that you managed to burn the chicken, and that even the soup had a burnt taste to it -- that takes talent. The one star is for the fact that the green beans were crispy (probably because they were burned, too). But I'm sad to say that a couple of months of buildup led to an utter disappointment.Never, never again.
The burrito was amazing AND humongous. Only thing I would ask, would be to have more sour cream in the burrito. I like tasting the coldness contrasting against the heat.

I had the most wonderful birthday dinner here a week ago. My party of 8 all LOVED their entrees, we all brought our own favorite wine, and the staff was so friendly and sweet. It's always a bit stressful picking a restaurant for your birthday, and hoping everyone will like it, atmosphere, good for groups, etc etc... but I honestly can say that this was the perfect choice. People would not stop talking about how good the dinner was. I cannot recommend this little gem enough.Now if only they did delivery to lower haight! hehehe
Very good food, great location and great service. The bathroom line can get a bit long and they can manage that better I would suggest.

I've been going here for years and just now realized I hadn't reviewed it yet! The XLBs (as all the cool kids call them) come out toasty and quickly, born in flavor and steam. I almost always get #1, and for good reason. It's always full of broth, always little bites of perfection. Best XLBs ever? Probably not... But good for location and proximity to my home. I've tried the other, more famous, XLB restaurant and I prefer these to theirs. That said, other delicious menu items include dry fried wings, •_green onion pancake, •_DAN DAN MEIN (yaaaaaas!!!), and lastly, •_to cap off your meal, the fried sugar ball. Fried, warm, crispy, fluffy dough rolled in sugar •_- •_uhhggnnnnn heaven on earth. Order soy milk to dip dat shet in and you gots a winner. Service? Quick. It's an Asian restaurant in the outer sunset... Don't expect much. Patrons? Mixed. It's great - •_most Chinese restaurants in the outer sunset you expect all Chinese people eating... But you get a good mixed crowd. I knocked a star off because the last time I ate, it wasn't as good as my previous experiences.

Have you ever had a taco so good it made you rethink your life? This is precisely what just happened. My girlfriend and I just came to La Taqueria after a recommendation from the guy at the front desk at our hotel and we were blown away. I actually said to my girlfriend at one point "I wish getting full wasn't a thing so I could just keep eating this". The super taco has melted cheese, your choice of meat, pico, beans(I opted out of), sour cream, and guacamole and was incredible. I bought two thinking they'd be more like street taco sized and was full after the first. The chips and salsa are great, it's just a basket of chips covered in an awesome pico de gallo. Chips come in handy for scooping up mounds of guacamole from tacos too! The place was crazy busy and seating was sparse so you have to hound down people that are about to tap out but other than that was some of the best Mexican food I've had in a long time!

Pasquale's has become one of my favorites and go-to places not only for pizzas, but for Italian food. I came here a few years ago and completely fell in love with the items on the menu. I love that this place closes late as well! Nowadays, I usually order an appetizer and pizza if I'm with friends, but I have tried a good selection of what they have here. I am a big fan of their lasagnas and stuffed potatoes! The servers are usually always nice and they always come by to fill up our waters and pack up our leftover food. I'm so glad that even throughout the years that this place has not changed.

Decided to give this place a try, though being in Japantown, why we didn't opt for a better-rated Japanese place is beyond me (I blame my brother who insisted on jja jang myun...)Though we were early for the dinner "rush," the restaurant was completely empty and just old-fashioned in its decor. The 'fish tank' in the front was half filled with water and more like a seaweed/algae tank. That should have been enough to re-think the decision.We went with the staples of jja jang myun (black bean noodles), tang soo yook, and kkan poong gi. The jja jang myun was very average. •_The tang soo yook was too crispy in my opinion, lacking in the gooey sweet and sour sauce to soften it up. The kkang poong gi was just a bad choice altogether - it came out as regular wings with no sauce. •_The seasoning on it was decent but the wings themselves were so dry.Nothing was impressive except the old waitress who spoke Korean, Chinese, and English.

this place has been on my list for ages and ages, and since my client is now in the mission, i tried the tea leaf salad for lunch. prices have gone up by $0.25 on every menu item. sooo the salad looks quite sizeable on yelp photos, but in real life it's tiny. i thought i could eat it like an entree - no go - but it was pretty good even in a takeout box with all dressing mixed in. service is basically non existent and the lady taking your order is quite rude... but. i will be back a few more times to try the rice and noodle dishes. not ready to give up on this spot just yet!

If you haven't tried the infamous truck you have to, or just stop in at their storefront. I love the baked buns, which are brown and more filling, but there were SOOO EXPENSIVE. So instead I opted for the regular white buns, but still good. I docked a star for price...they are ridiculously overpriced. But they are tasty. Flavorful, different variations and combinations. Pork belly is good. Tender belly with the tartness of the daikon- perfect balancing of flavors. Braised short rib, also tender, went well with the slaw. •_Braised pork also delicious. The only one I didn't care for was the spicy chicken. Nothing I could afford on the regular, but so good I have to treat myself occasionally :)

great prices and a large selection of options too. several vegetarian options as well. i enjoyed the spinach papusas with rice and beans on the side. the pickled cabbage the papuas are served with is great as well.

There's a reason there's a big line to get served on a Saturday. •_The sandwiches are fantastic. •_Even though the line is long, it moves pretty fast.Everyone has different tastes in sandwiches so have at it. •_I just recommend the special sauce and the dutch crunch bread. •_You won't be disappointed.Wow.
This is one of my favorite spots. It's our go-to for Vietnamese take out. Warm and delicious, great soups, and if you can do it, the porridge with the thousand year egg is the thing to get.

Had an enjoyable dinner here the other night. The staff were friendly and polite, and the waiter checked on us regularly. Only reason for the star deduction is our food came out so fast we hadn't finished our soup and salad and were left with a table quite crowded with plates and bowls. •_Other than that it was a pleasant and nice experience. It's an Olive Garden, so it's not that different from other locations because their brand is (in my opinion) pretty good at consistency.

I am SO picky with my burgers and this place blew me away. It's sort of... grungy inside, hence the name Garaje. It is very properly named, but I am known for loving hole in the wall spots, so of course I had to try this! When I was in SF, I wanted to eat like a local and not a tourist, which is why I tend to turn to Yelp. When I saw this place, I knew I had to go. BRING CASH. I will probably write that again because somehow I missed it when I went and had to use the ATM, but whatever, still worth it. The food took awhile to prepare, but I would rather it take longer and be fresh than be frozen. There were all sorts of different people here and somehow people were doing coding (it's dark, so don't try to read a book here by any means) but it was very cool to people watch here as well. When we got our food, I seriously inhaled it because it was so good. I got a regular cheeseburger and fries (which were extra) and I had no regrets. I will come back to this place every time I visit SF and will rave about it to everyone and anyone I know!!

3 stars for having a lot of vegetarian options on the menu, but there's a few things wrong with this restaurant. Doesn't seem to be much care in cooking the food. My onion cake was almost burned on one side, almost raw on the other side. The hot and sour soup was kind of boring. Had to add some soy sauce. Not much hot or sour in it. The veggie kung pao chicken had large chunks of veggie chicken, almost too big to eat without cutting. The rest of the veggies were just large pieces of zucchini. Not very spicy either. They need to put more emphasis on the food. There's nothing to distinguish it. And there's a lot of competition, most of it better quality.

You know about the food. •_You know about the service. •_But do you really know about the people who work there?It's one thing to give poor service. •_But don't treat your customers like the step children you abandoned. •_The look of that one lady's eyes gives me the impression that she's really unhappy with the rise of property taxes or she just hates how her life turned out. •_I was taking a picture of the other lady cooking and from the corner of my ear I hear a...NO PICTUREEEEEEEEEEEE!So I was like, "Dude...chill. •_Good God."And then she continued to cuss me out in Burmese, but didn't have the guts to say it to my face.Like was that really necessary?Just say, "hey, buddy. •_No pictures."I mean, just because your life looks like a war zone doesn't mean you gotta take it out on everyone else.And what's so bad about taking a picture? •_It's giving you business.I appreciate a good hole in a wall, but the service reminds me of that one hole in the wall where the homeless drop deuces.

The man who (as far as I can tell) owns/runs this place is incredibly kind, and cares a lot about keeping you and your table happy. On top of his cordial service, YYH offers close to 100 dishes, many of which are vegetarian, and vegan.The portions are huge! Two dishes could easily feed three or four people depending on your appetites. Even the appetizers are generously plated - to reiterate Bri L's review, the potstickers alone could serve as a meal if you're looking to save a couple bucks. In fact, I did just that yesterday.

Okay okay okay. So even though it had a health score of like fucking 59 last year, I would still willingly poison myself with this deliciousness. Eric's is pretty much the only Chinese food place I will go to in the city without hesitation (well, them and Alice's, but isn't Alice's like Eric's doppelganger little sister or some shit?). The lemon chicken cannot be denied here. And your will power is nothing against the 5 taste chicken or the broccoli beef. And lets not go there with the hot and sour soup because girlfriend will sit here and talk about how tits it is for houuuurrrs. Seriously, I am a bitch when it comes to my chinese food but Eric's knows how to do it right and girl is not trying to fight it no mo! I always give in when someone says "How bout Eric's" How bout I'm already seated and waiting for you to make up your damn mind on what you want!

GO HERE!!! My family and I were in the area looking for Chinese food to eat at. It was around 8:30 pm. We came to Nan King Road Bistro hoping what the yelp reviews said were true. They were RIGHT!!! Food: We ordered wonton soup, chicken fried rice, crispy noodles, honey walnut shrimp, calamari, and eggplant with chicken. (A lot... I know...lol) Everything was made fresh and FAST. Calamari was my favorite. All the vegetables used tasted fresh and great.Service: What sold me about this place was the service. When we asked for vinegar, the manager came back with vinegar instead of our waitress. He noticed me taking a picture of the food and said "Wow, very good picture." He came back 5 minutes later with Crispy Sesame Chicken, and said "This is what our customers love the most, free of charge." This was a whole order full of chicken, not those small samples plates. I figured he thought I was going to write a review on yelp even though I've never made a yelp review in my life. So now I feel this place was that worth it to make a review. My family and I will definitely be back!

Was trying to get there last night, but the hostess was so rude that we had to leave. After asking a bunch of questions like: are you sure that you want to eat in our place, and showing the menu,bc my bf was wearing a simple t-shirt and not a suit,she was pretty confused about this situation with us,peasants,but finally decided to let us make a reservation.thanks.but when I came in and asked for her name bc of her rudeness,she told me with a super fake smile that we should leave. Actually this is the first time in my life when I came across such a behavior. So if you have a bow tie in your pocket and you want to deal with a rude personal-this place is for you.I'm super sorry that we didn't try the pizza,according to the reviews it's pretty good, and one star just for the rude hostess,bc if one element doesn't work appropriately-the whole system suffers
My absolute favorite breakfast place in the world. The line is worth it. Go for the eggs Benedict- try the original before branching out to the other kinds. Mmmmmm...

Where are we?! Did the server just smile at me AND say thank you . . . at a dim sum place?! Say whaaaa?!?!? •_Just for that, I'm definitely coming back! Ha! Seriously tho, for a dim sum place this is pretty fancy!- It's CLEAN! No really, even the bathrooms are clean :)-Service with a smile! There was an issue getting our table but they were very apologetic. During our meal, there were lot's of smiles and thank you's. Soooo not used to that at any Asian place!-RESERVATIONS! I've never even heard of a dim sum place accepting reservations! Call in or use the Open Table app-Modernized! They'll text you when your table is ready. And the cart waitresses have headsets to communicate. So, if you're looking for a certain dish they'll call over the cart waitress to come to your table.-Great food . . . the XLB (Shanghai Soup Dumplings) and the warm egg custard tarts were ahhhh-mazing!!!One star taken off for the price. Its just way too pricey for the quantity and portion of the food. I believe for 6 of the XLB's was $14 and about $11 for 4 egg custards. Can't remember any of the other prices since I wasn't in charge of collecting the money (thank goodness! I hate that job!). We came in as a party of 6 and I must have put down almost $50 for my share. Its so easy to get carried away when all those carts pass by!

One of the best pizza restaurants I've ever been to! We luckily found parking in the street and was able to walk just about 20 seconds to the restaurant. There was also no line and was seated immediately! Temperature was amazing so we sat outside.We ordered the Margherita pizza (they only make 73[?] of them a day!) and some of their fries. I highly suggest getting their fries! It's more on the sweet side but it also had bits of bacon in it to give a boost of a flavor.Customer service here was outstanding! Our server was prompt and refilled our water when it gets half empty.Would definitely love to come back here again!

Amazing food and even better service. This restaurant is loud and a ton of fun. There is no shortage of loud music in Italian and a staff who knows every word. The carpaccio is not to be missed, gnocchi, sausage pasta and orange tiramisu. If I could give this place more then 5 stars I would.

Indeed it is not authentic Mexican food, but frankly very little of the places in SF are authentic (startle!)...even in the Mission. •_Many SF hipsters are apparently expert identifiers of culturally authentic cuisine (it's the SMUG, you can't blame them). •_If you are actually from Mexico, there are pray few places in this city where you get the real deal. •_Tia's (a-duh!) ain't one of em. •_Was it the sports bar look that fooled you? •_ •_That being said, it's mostly good Margaritas and Americanized-Californiazed (whatever the hell that means) comfort food. •_For Christ's sake they have Taquitos like out of the oven. •_and another downside is the tv only play sports, but you can tune that out. •_Come here on a weeknight after a shitty day at work with a good friend. •_Come around 8pm (the screaming food-throwing crotchfruit are gone then). •_Grab a Margarita and a beer as a chaser, order some comfort food, and if you are an SF overgroomed metrosexual food-rater attempting to judge a restaurant strictly along cultural guidelines, there's this country just south of here called Mexico, where you can get a great, culturally idiosyncratic burrito.

Second time here and a little disappointed. Their "Super Burritos" are extremely simple and pretty dry. The chicken was large chunks, most of them were blackened giving it a burnt taste. Then just rice, beans, a little cheese and Pico de gallo. To be fair, they dont list the ingredients of what a "super burrito" is, but there is no sour cream, guacamole, lettuce or anything that is usually standard in a "Super". Price and size is decent, but I'd rather pay a little more for a burrito that wasn't so bland and dry.I would say the tacos are the better buy. Very large, filling, and tasty.

Gracias Madre was so friggin delicious, and that's being said despite the fact that everything here is vegan! Note: I myself am not a vegan and this was one of the first vegan restaurants I've been too. Needless to say--I was pleasantly surprised. I came here at noon with a friend today (a Thursday). We got seated immediately (no crazy lunch line woohoo) and it was pretty empty inside. I ordered the Bowl Dos, my friend got the Bowl Uno, and we split the Gorditas appetizer (fried potato thingy).The appetizer was crunchy and chewy, and not super amazing but the salsas they serve there (the red one!!) with it made it way more flavorful and tasty. The Bowl dos was SO delicious and satisfying with so much depth from the beans and creamy sauces and also brightness and a kick from the spicy salsa with pineapple (the pineapple in the salsa really gave the dish a nice sweetness/acidity and balanced out all of the flavors). There was so much going on, with the fragrant coconut brown rice, fresh greens on top, savory beans and sauces, etc. etc. I didn't think once "dangit where's the meat to make this more savory/flavorful/satisfying?" because it was perfectly delicious without it! My friend's Bowl was not as flavorful as mine (whoops sorry I'm that person who orders the better dish than the other when we "split it" heh heh) but had cashew cheese/cream which was savory (but not as delicious as my pineapple salsa heh...).The bill for a bowl and appetizer came out to be around $23/person (for lunch). Kind of super pricey and makes me very very sad, but the fact that this place is vegan and delicious AND filling (a rarity in SF) makes it a little less painful. I give this place 5 stars despite the expensive price because I think everyone should stop by and give vegan food a try! You'll be surprised at how delicious it is, and your body will thank you for making this healthy (ish) choice.

Gracias Madre was so friggin delicious, and that's being said despite the fact that everything here is vegan! Note: I myself am not a vegan and this was one of the first vegan restaurants I've been too. Needless to say--I was pleasantly surprised. I came here at noon with a friend today (a Thursday). We got seated immediately (no crazy lunch line woohoo) and it was pretty empty inside. I ordered the Bowl Dos, my friend got the Bowl Uno, and we split the Gorditas appetizer (fried potato thingy).The appetizer was crunchy and chewy, and not super amazing but the salsas they serve there (the red one!!) with it made it way more flavorful and tasty. The Bowl dos was SO delicious and satisfying with so much depth from the beans and creamy sauces and also brightness and a kick from the spicy salsa with pineapple (the pineapple in the salsa really gave the dish a nice sweetness/acidity and balanced out all of the flavors). There was so much going on, with the fragrant coconut brown rice, fresh greens on top, savory beans and sauces, etc. etc. I didn't think once "dangit where's the meat to make this more savory/flavorful/satisfying?" because it was perfectly delicious without it! My friend's Bowl was not as flavorful as mine (whoops sorry I'm that person who orders the better dish than the other when we "split it" heh heh) but had cashew cheese/cream which was savory (but not as delicious as my pineapple salsa heh...).The bill for a bowl and appetizer came out to be around $23/person (for lunch). Kind of super pricey and makes me very very sad, but the fact that this place is vegan and delicious AND filling (a rarity in SF) makes it a little less painful. I give this place 5 stars despite the expensive price because I think everyone should stop by and give vegan food a try! You'll be surprised at how delicious it is, and your body will thank you for making this healthy (ish) choice.

Tacos and burritos are fine enough but the line and the crowds are not worth it. The owner is super nice and the workers do a very good job of cleaning up around as people leave. However, If I had to do it over again I would have passed on this place.

Short Version:I like this place. It's got a cool ambiance, very attentive and polite service, good food, and a huge selection of hard liquor. If it was up to me, I'd come by for drinks and a small bite to eat, or light meal before going out to a club. Their entrees are a little pricey for the small portions they give, but you don't really wanna stuff yourself before you go out, do you?Extended Version:Hakka Steamed Dim Sum Platter - 3 stars- You get four different pairs of dumplings. I liked the Chinese Chive Dumpling (3 1/2 stars) the most, then the Black Pepper Duck Dumpling (3 1/2 stars), which tasted a little like they used East Indian spices to make it, the Scallop Shumai (3 stars), and the Har Gau (3 stars)- On the menu, this is meant to be an appetizer, but if you're eating it by yourself, it should be enough to fill you upyelp.com/biz_photos/hakk_Ü_Wok-Fry Beef Tenderloin w/ Chinese Celery - 3 1/2 stars- This is my favorite dish here so far, and adding the Chili Oil (3 1/2 stars) made it even better (the Chili Sauce is good too, just not as good as the oil)- Portions were pretty small, but with a side of Steamed Jasmine Rice (3 stars) for $2, and a good portion of Egg and Scallion Fried Rice (3 1/2 stars) for $5, it's more than enough to fill up most people up to 200 lbsyelp.com/biz_photos/hakk_Ü_yelp.com/biz_photos/hakk_Ü_yelp.com/biz_photos/hakk_Ü_Crispy Duck Salad - 3 stars- It's not the kind of salad you expect since there is no lettuce in it, just "micro-greens". Tasted decent, and the duck was cooked well, but I still prefer the beef dishBraised Free-Range Chicken w/ Angelica Root - 3 stars- Looked at this and saw a piece of chicken with bone and barely any meat, then other pieces of chicken w/ their skin on it and I didn't expect it to be good, but I was surprised. It's a lot better than it looks, and the chicken skin practically melts in your mouthMisc.- For the first few minutes, I thought someone there was gassy because every few feet smelled like someone may have farted, but later on we figured out that it was just the smell from one of their menu items (don't remember which one though)

This place must be lovers' spot. My boyfriend and I first came here when we were looking for a place to eat when I first got here in the bay. The heated outdoor seating and the dim lighting dragged our feet to its doorstep. When we got inside, the decor is amazing. Its like a big italian pantry. They also have a bar area where you could get some drinks while waiting to be seated. This place could get really crowded, don't get too easily discouraged and walk away because the answer is right when you hold that menu with very affordable prices and it would just get better once you get your generous portion of food and the taste is surprisingly good.Now, I must say their tables for two are pretty small and it could get crowded once your food arrives. So if you think you'll have a lot of food on the table, try to request to have yourselves seated in a bigger table. We came to this place 3 or 4 times and we always loved it. We sure will come back again.

This review is for eat in and take out.  Either way you get absolutely crapola service. That's never ever gonna improve. The people working here are bummed the f--- out. Who knows exactly why and who cares. Be a f--ing professional. SF has officially now become the forgotten step sister to NYC. Like a step sister she is disintegrating into a shell of rotten urine smells just like the good old mission always has. For the prices Danny Bowen (I spelled his name wrong on purpose) can make the not cool dirty restaurant cleaner, •_AT LEAST. At most he can respect that SF put him on the map and share the love with us. the food score is 86?? WTF?? •_Which brings me to the food. It's a great concept. It's crap execution. and the revolting open kitchen is no help. I don't care if this was the original and use better quality meats and veggies (they don't). When the place stinks worse than Sam Wo's it's no wonder they keep the lights so dim. It's to hide the gross factor. Suck it Danny. All the way to the bank. But this guy is f'n gone for good. Later, Byaaaatch. $37 with tip for takeout noodles. F- it!!

I find myself here every 2 weeks now, (since July 2013) and I have no regrets or intention to stop coming even though its a 50 minute drive to get some fresh, hot pizza. If this is the closest I'll get to Naples, then its absolutely worth it. Although my wallet says otherwise ;p

Things I enjoyed:- The foods were wonderful and drinks got me suitably sugar high/ slightly buzzed- The view- The staff are super friendly!- Hella dudes buy you drinks while you wait for-freaking-ever for your friends to get up the elevator- Everyone is having a super fun time :DThings I decidedly did not enjoy:- The line (at 6pm?) paaaaalaese- Totes bro-land/ meat-marketing thing going on... it had a strange resemblance to what Lime used to be (if you know what I mean, then you know what I mean)

Not all Gordos are created equal. I have sampled, this one is by far the best, the one on Irving rolls loose sloppy burritos, the one on geary seems to have things sitting out longer. This one on clement is always fast, things seem fresh, choose this one you won't be disappointed.
Went hunting around North Beach to find pizza by the slice. Found this spot, converted an old dive bar to a pizza joint, looks awesome here!!! Love it! Definitely coming back!!

I would absolutely not recommend Hong Kong Lounge 2. I should say that my party didn't do dim sum and ordered from the entree menu instead. The dim sum seems decent according to other reviews, which is a shame because I won't be returning to find out.First off, the ambience is just depressing. It was pretty dark inside on our visit and between the unpleasant color of the walls and the dark carpet, the whole place had a rather surreal (like spooky surreal) vibe.Anyways, I tend to associate this place with how its decor, and not its food, affected me which probably tells you what you need to know about the food. It wasn't bad--basically the same stuff you could get at any average place in chinatown--just horribly overpriced. In addition, I remember being surprised by my bill because we got charged for things that the server didn't mention were extra and usually aren't extra. I think they got us on refills for either the tea or the white rice? For me, transparency is pretty important and you won't find much of it behind the frosted windows of HKL2.

My bf and I stopped here on a Saturday night at 7. •_The wait was 2 hours without a reservation. •_There were empty seats at the bar, so we ate there.The bartender was nice. •_He was attentive. •_Our water glasses were always full.There was hype about the bread. •_We had the complementary bread basket, which was forgettable. •_The orecchiette (pasta with sausage) was delicious, but it was $24, which I thought was over priced. •_The salad (Coastal Greens) was pretty plain and was equally overpriced at $10. •_Long Island was $12 and my lemon drop was $10.
izzeria|

GREAT experience! The food, atmosphere, and service were all amazing. The only downside I can really think of is the wait times; we waited for our seat for about 30 minutes due to how busy it was. The food took a little while too, but it wasn't that crazy.The noise level was pretty loud, especially because it was a Saturday evening, but that didn't bother us too much.However, these really weren't major problems for us. It was overall a very good experience,and I would definitely recommend this place to someone looking for high quality Italian food!

A little store front in the mist of Chinatown in SF. Not the friendliest service nor the most sanitary place, but is the food delicious! Greeted by 2 ladies that didn't care to suggest anything and just waited impatiently to order my to go dim sum selections. Ended with sesame balls (which were gia-nomrous), shu mai, and har gow. They sell in orders of 1 or 3 I believe, I opted for 3 for all 3 choices. The prices ranged from $1.50-$3.00, which is crazy cheap for the size the items.What I thought was not sanitary is that they would wear gloves to get your food, but give you money and change with the same glove. Doesn't that defeat the purpose of that? Money is one of the dirtiest thing in the world. Anyways, come with a strong stomach and enjoy these deliciousness on the street!
Finally made it here and loved it. The wine list was great and the infamous chicken over the bread salad lived up to the hype.
Stopped by here after Crissy Field and got the margherita! The mozzarella just oozes!! Def Can't go wrong with this classic. So good! I'll def stop by again when in the neighborhood!

If you love garlic this is the place to be! Great clams! I am always looking for good clams. The atmosphere is fun and has fun gift shop that you can by some of there products or clothing. Make sure you make a reservation!!
I was a little disappointed. There are so many positive reviews. I found the pizza to be just OK. I got a margarita pizza. The cheese was very rubbery. The crust was good, not great.

They say location is everything. Thanks to the Outer Sunset's cold and foggy microclimate, The Pot's definitely caters the perfect meal for this type of weather. My experience with hot pots have been limited to Little Sheep, but The Pot's has a lot more variety and better quality ingredients. There were 13 different soup bases to choose from! While the fire spicy may look intimidating, it's not that bad if you exclusively cook the meats in there separate from your vegetables. We split half that soup base with the coconut pork bone for some variety.In addition to the soup bases, there were so many meat, seafood, and dumpling choices. All the ingredients looked fresh, not frozen including the meatballs. The variety of noodles was vast as well. Favorites included the lamb, enoki mushrooms, ramen noodles, fish fillet, and the many different types of dumplings. Dinner was limited to 90 minutes and came out to be around $35 per person with tax and tip. This place was insanely packed at dinner so I recommend getting here by 6:00 pm at the latest for a walk-in table.

I've been here three times for dinner and once for breakfast. •_I've had the saltimbocca (excellent), the gnocchi piemontese (very good), and the risotto frutti di mare (good). •_The breakfast was an eggs florentine (very good). •_The dinners were all busy, and we had to wait about 5-10 minutes to get in. •_The breakfast was fast. •_Service was a little slow, but friendly and accurate. •_Wine selection is okay. Food: 4.5 starsService: 3 starsAmbiance: 3.5 starsPrice: 4 starsOverall it's a good solid contributor to North Beach's Italian eatery set. •_I'll go back.

Cheap, but you get what you pay for. Truly a takeout dim sum place, and they should make that clearer. At noon on a Sunday, we found the food was barely warm. When we asked the employee to warm it up in the microwave, we were met with a cringing, reluctant look. Best if you buy it back and warm it up in the comfort of your own home.The portions were large and filling, but that might be because they used a lot of flour in the dishes with wraps or buns and the "skin" wrappings were very thick. The rice noodle roll (cheong fun) in particular had thicker than normal skin, so by the end we started picking out the meat to eat instead.FYI, the Shanghai dumplings here are done in a different style with the flour buns instead of the dumpling soup wrap that is seen in some dim sum places.

Food is pretty decent Beijing-style.Actually it's very good, I'm just not a huge fan of the Beijing-style xiaolongbao, and the dan dan noodle (was that it?)'s sauce was waaay too salty.They actually manage to have parking, they can handle a decent sized group, and even if the kitchen is a smidgen slow (maybe I was just impatient?) the price is right for what amounts to a fairly authentic Chinese dive.I suspect it's a 4-star place, but for the reasons above, it just didn't work for me. They've got a generous menu, I clearly need to explore more of it before passing a more comprehensive judgement.

Came here with a group of 10 for brunch...that was an ordeal in itself. *sigh. •_I wanted to come around 12, and they only had 11AM open...when they opened. My group got here a bit early and waited around outside a bit. We saw the staff get prepped and ready to go, which is kind of nice.The place itself feels huge. Giant space, open plans, a loft upstairs that overlooks the downstairs. Only strange thing is looking at their awning from above - its quite dirty...and after a light shower, its really apparent that no one washes that thing.The food was mostly just OK. The portions are quite small, so don't expect to fill up on just one order.French Toast: One of the better items I had. If I could stand an entire meal of sweet, I'd go for this.Flank Steak: tiny portion. Their sauce was the best part of this. Our waiter made a note to clarify that their mid-rare would be fine with me, and I said yes. Except...now I'm expecting mid-rare, and they gave me something closer to medium. Sad face.Sausage: Pretty delicious. Also tiny portion. The sausage itself was moist. Roasted Chicken with Bread Salad: It IS worth the hype. The chicken was delicious, and very moist. The bread salad...was a little too greasy and sour (I assume they used some sort of sourdough bread). But the chicken was delicious.

I used to have a good friend who lived near the Velvet Cantina and would go there when visiting him. •_This was in 2009/2010 and hadn't been back since this past weekend.My girlfriend and I were in town for the weekend and we stopped in on Saturday night. •_Got seated fairly quickly and everything was perfect as always. •_Chips and salsa are fresh and delicious, awesome margaritas, and great food. •_My girlfriend doesn't like spicy food and she asked a head of time how spicy her enchiladas were. •_The waiter said nothing was too overpowering or spicy with the exception of the shrimp diablo. •_She ordered the Verde enchiladas and they were a little too spicy for her. •_The waiter noticed she hadn't touched her food and offered to replace it. •_She said it was OK and just asked for some warm tortillas to make tacos with her beans and rice. •_He was very helpful and brought them by. •_When we got our bill he had removed her meal from the receipt since she didn't like it. •_Always nice to see an employee going above and beyond, especially when the restaurant was busy and he didn't have to do so.

I don't think the food is that great here but this place always has a line during lunch. •_I've been there a couple of times with colleagues or friends that want to eat there. •_The food is a very generic Americanized Mexican food that's heavy and flavorless. •_The food is often topped with load of cheese

Have to agree with other reviews. House of Nan King (HONK) used to be way better back when they just had counter seating. It was actually kind of amusing how "unrefined" the service was but that's not why you went there. You went there to get an honest Chinese meal for an honest price. •_You'll still get a great meal here but it won't resemble the Chinese comfort foods you were used to as a kid. You could say the food has evolved to appeal to broader palettes so it's maybe not as authentic as I remembered it to be.
I go to eat here often. I order the spicy green beans and lemon grass chicken. nice people work there! •_The the best chinese place in the city!!

consistency is the key for this veteran of the sunset rice soup and noodle house ... efficiently served hot food, again won ton and rice soup no more, no less, the turnip cakes are a speciality ... not grandma's, but hey, she aint here no more ...

Loved the Sangria and it appeared everyone else sitting at the bar did too. Rubbed Pork was wonderful. Every order of the Guacamole is freshly made and really tasted great. •_Rice and beans were lovely.Really loved this place. Staff was attentive and personable. Will definitively go back many times and program into •_my cellie for to-go on the many nights this place is jammed.Entrees were $9-12 and decent sized portions. I couldn't finish mine and took it to go.

Not bad. Ordered the carne asada super burrito, which is pretty big. Partner had the carne asada plate, also good size. And the super nachos. Which may have been too much since each order gets its own chips and salsa. Cheap prices. Oh, I did like the cantaloupe juice yum.We're from Texas. Specifically San Antonio, and we're constantly in search of good Mexican food in SF. We really thought this place would be it. We love taquerias! But I dunno there was just something missing from the flavor of the asada. Just not salty or fatty enough LOL. And the refried beans are too runny, not thick and fatty like in SA. And the nachos.. forget about it! They are supposed to be put in the oven hello!? Aaggh I miss REAL Mexican food!! What is up with this type of "Mexican" food found here in SF?!?! Ugh and it really irks me everything's about burritos here. I don't think I ever ate burritos in Texas! There's so much much much much more to Mexican food!!!! I need to visit Texas stat! :D But I love SF don't get me wrong LOL

Yes, yes, and more yes. •_The Guac is awesome, I love the tacos here, and they have great beer specials on Friday. •_There is outdoor seating, tons of hot sauce, great music, lots of items on the menu, and everything tastes good here. •_What's missing? •_Hmmmmm. •_Oh. •_I know! •_I know!Yes Ryan?Margaritas! •_(cue "tada" sound) •_Yup...no margaritas at a Mexican restaurant is like watching a Nascar race where no one spins out, crashes, bumps fenders, or flashes an off-toothed smile. •_They have attempted to counteract this problem with agave margarita flavored wine thingys which taste like the super sugary pre-mixed powder crud you buy at the 5 and dime.Alas, the food is awesome but the lack of tequila goodness robs them of the 5th star.
jumbo shrimp in hot pepper sauce--not really too spicy but oh so delicioso!!!!!

Delicious Singapore style noodles and General Tsao's Chicken. The owner Ming and Alice the waitress are both very friendly and personable and willing to accommodate food allergies and preferences. AND they allow separate checks which is amazingly helpful! I've been a regular for several years.

Don't expect to be waited on here. •_Grab any server if you need anything. •_Get use to sharing tables when there is a wait. •_My favorite Xiao Long Bao did not disappoint. •_The soup in the dumpling were delicious. •_Spicy crab dumplings were good. •_Pot stickers are okay.Green Onion fried pancake was delicious but could have been more crisp!I could have done without the Sugar Egg Puffs with all the main dishes I had devoured prior. •_You can skip this.Overall Shanghai Dumpling King is a great meal on a budget.

No clue why people wait 1-2 hours for this place. I suppose their French toasts are slightly unique, but otherwise it's a pretty basic breakfast. Sooo many other places to go in the city. On a personal note, I could not eat the food there: Once you are inside at the cashier, you watch all the men in the open kitchen. They do not wear gloves to make the food and, after watching all of their hands repeatedly dunk into the vat of egg batter, and all over everything, I became super grossed out and couldn't eat. It felt really dirty to me. I realize some people don't care, but I had no appetite after watching their hands all over my food.

Tropisueno's no taqueria. It's upper scale Mexican for a decent price tag and while the food is definitely above average, I think they might have one of the best Margarita/free chips and salsa combo's in San Francisco...err at least in the financial district. They bring a huge pile of chips fresh from the oven and they keep 'em coming. Served with three different spice intensities, you could almost make a meal out of it if the salsas were a bit thicker. Margs are a perfect balance of sweet and sour and for under $8 you're getting a steal for the area. Overall it's a great place for happy hour and if you don't fill up on free chips an excellent option to stay for dinner as well.
exican Kitchen|
I thought the food was pretty decent. Not great, but good. Just pretty basic fare. Nice wait staff and a friendly restaurant overall. Just didn't blow me away within any exquisite flavors, etc.

Went there once with coworkers. Took 2 tries to get seat. Dumpling taste good and I especially like the Tom Yum dumplings. Price is trying to be in MY.CHINA or Yank Sink range. Tried another time with friends on Saturdays and both times restaurant is closed for private events. Verdict: Overrated.

I love El Toreador the most. From its cluttered, decorative decor to its delicious Mexican fare, to me it is really the show stopper of West Portal.I recently brought my boyfriend here on the Fourth of July no less, as we are both big time Mexican food enthusiasts. I ordered the fish tacos, although I was a little reticent to do so considering they use fried fish, which tends to not be my favorite. I usually love fish tacos with grilled fish-it's healthier and tastes fresher. Actually, at ET, I usually order the spinach enchiladas, which are crazy delicious and a great choice if you are vegetarian, but I decided to branch out. •_The fish tacos ended up being a fantastic choice! I only needed one of those bad boys--they were huge! The fish was delicious, perfectly cooked and flavorful. The batter was light and flaky, and the pico de gallo was as fresh as can be. The dish was served with a small cup of black beans and a small cup of Spanish rice--I appreciated the moderate portion size. •_My boyfriend ordered one of specials: the Basa (fish), served with refried beans and Spanish rice. I was perplexed by the order--I prefer that my dining partners order something that I can eat at least half of--and I wasn't sure fish would be the best order for that. Boy howdy, was I wrong! That fish was slammin! It was cooked perfectly, seasoned perfectly, and garnished with some insanely delicious sauce I'd like to take a bath in. My man cleaned his plate--it was so yummy! My sister loves the cheese enchilada with green sauce. I have to note how much I love ET's salsa--it's worth a trip to ET just for the salsa! This sentiment is reflected in nearly every review of ET I've read. You know I loves the heat! I also have to mention the margaritas. We ordered a pitcher of fruit punch margaritas (see picture). We LOVED it! Hands down, one of the best margaritas I've ever had. We had such great service--it was really impressive. Our salsa was refilled without asking. Our waters were kept filled. Our food was served hot and delicious. Our server was friendly and fun.On the bathroom wall: "Don't question authority, they don't know either."The only bad aspect worth mentioning was that although the restaurant was pretty empty, a large woman and her friend were sat in the two top just behind me - and she kept pushing against the back of my seat and asking me to move my purse, etc. I'm not sure if ET sat them there or they demanded to sit at that particular table, but it was not the best. Lucky for them, we had killed that pitcher of margaritas so I didn't REALLY care, but it was annoying. Overall, awesome. It's my favorite place in West Portal, for sure.

Wow - by far one of the best meals I've had in SF. Here's what was mind-blowing:-brassicas and grains (fresh and delicious)-hen of the mushroom (out of this world good)-scallops (amazing, great texture)-pear bread pudding -wine list - don't hesitate to ask for recos if you're not an aficionado •_The smoked fettucini was great but not as delish as the others. The wait is long and it can be pricey, but it more than makes up for it.

I can't rave enough about San Tung. I used to never get the hype, how good can chicken wings actually be? Pretty damn good. That is the answer. These chicken wings are amazing. My recommendation would be to go before they open so that you can snag a seat once they open. If you miss the first seating, you better be willing to wait. There is San Tung 2 next door, but people say that it doesn't compare to the original. The dumplings were amazing, but the show-stealer was definitely those tasty wings. The green beans were also very tasty. I glanced at the weekday lunch menu and saw that they had some very affordable offerings, so that is something I will need to check off my list eventually.
We love El Metate's burritos; generously sized

Came here once over a year ago and the super burrito with everything I've ordered was one to die or let's say live for lol! The ingredients were fresh and they'll roll your order right in front of you just like Subways. No wonder why this spot was jammed pack that night and continues to be! Ideal Mexican spot in the Mission. Parking can be a hassle for majority of the day and there could be a long line but well worth the wait!
Nice people, good environment. Unfortunately, the food is mediocre at best. There are so many great taco shops in the mission! You can do better.
Another hidden gem!! The "Gut Guide" leads to another treasure chest of food. Thanks to bro'!! RB Mushroom sandwich w/ Lou's sauce. Get it, got it, Umm!!

It's actually a 4.5 stars. •_We came in looking for brunch but it turns out they don't serve brunch. •_It was a nice space and we didn't want to get in the line at Just for You so we decided to stay. •_ We were glad we did! I ordered the salsiccia pizza with onions, and added mushrooms and an egg at the server's suggestion. •_It was delicious! •_One of the best thin crust pizzas I've had. •_So much better than the salsiccia pizza at Pizzeria Delfina, which had very few toppings and wasn't half as tasty. •_ I took half home and enjoyed it for dinner. •_My friend ordered the panini with fried green tomatoes and crescenza, which came with a small side salad with early girl tomatoes, and she loved it. •_We sat the counter and basically drooled over all the food getting prepared in front of us, including the ricotta torte (which apparently is only sold at the Piccino coffee bar around the corner), the quiche, and the olive oil cake which was layers of cake with raspberries, strawberries, and a lot of cream lathered around it. •_ The cooks were all very friendly and happy to answer the dozen questions we asked about what they were making. •_They serve Sightglass Coffee, which was very good, as well as Mr

Get the Monte Cristo! •_Enough said. •_This is by far the best and most unique dish I've had. •_Just be prepared to wait 45min+ in line on a regular weekend. •_You may get better luck to get in if it's a rainy day. •_Also bring enough cash on you as well. •_This place is cash only or debit card if you order +$15, which you probably would since most dishes are around that price anyways.The Monte Cristo's cheese, turkey and ham just melts in your mouth in between a french toast like bread. •_The savory treat is balanced with a slightly sweet homemade jam that just melts in your mouth. •_It's a really rich breakfast, so be prepared for some food coma afterwards. •_I've tried to get the Mama's cristo, which is their variation, but they only make a limited amount. •_The regular MOnte Cristo is one of their most popular dishes though. I've tried their crab and Blackstone (bacon) omelettes. •_However they were just average. •_Tastes good, but just average. •_Maybe I'll have to come back and try their salmon (recommended by the cashier) and/or their lobster omelette as well.Another thing I like about this place is surprisingly their special bloody mary. •_It was super hearty. •_I feel just drinking that made me full. •_Their special mix is pretty spicy. •_I would say spicier than many of the other restaurants I've tried. •_You can't even taste the alcohol when your'e drinking it. •_Though you'll definitely feel it afterwards. •_Overall, get the Monte Cristo and wash it down with some hearty bloody mary for a good start of the day!
I've dined at Crystal Jade several times
Total rip off. The food is OK quality but the price is staggering. For only 4-5 small dishes we are charged with hefty price. Came out bankrupted and still hungry.
Erica!! Why are u soo rude!! I come to this place twice a month and the way I was treated was insane!! Love the food but the raring is solely based on the way Erica treated us!!
talian Restaurant|

I'm not an expert of the streets of SF Chinatown, but the hustle and bustle reminds me of home enough that there's always a connection when I'm wandering around the neighborhood. •_Surprisingly, Chinatown doesn't have a good reputation when it comes to Chinese food, as a lot of it is seen as catering to tourists, serving Americanized Chinese food.Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant stands out from the touristy scene. •_I visited on a Thursday around lunchtime, and as soon as I walked up the stairs, I found the place packed with Cantonese locals getting their lunch on. •_It was so packed I ended up having to share a large table with some other people. •_The lunchtime specials here are cheap. •_I ordered a bowl of pig liver congee and a beef brisket with vegetables rice plate for 4.50 each. •_Portions were more than generous, too.The congee was decent. •_It wasn't the best I've had, especially since the , but the liver was good. •_It didn't taste funny, which liver sometimes does, and the texture wasn't rubbery either. •_Also, for $4.50, you get a good amount of it. •_The beef brisket was standard too. •_I was actually more impressed with the veggies. •_They tasted fresh and again, the portion size was generous. •_I was almost full after the congee that I didn't even touch the rice. •_Also, I should note that immediately upon sitting down, they gave me a bowl of complimentary soup. •_Not many restaurants continue doing that these days. •_It wasn't amazing, but you can't complain (too much) about free.Service: •_Efficient and they actually smile!Bottom line: •_Bargain for lunch!

I'm not from the city but when I do visit (and it's quite often) I always bug my friends to take me here. I have waited anywhere from 2 minutes to an hour for a seat. Cucumber Salad: beautifully seasoned. That sauce is bomb af! Perfect appetizer. Salt n Pepper Tofu: eh sub par. Could use a little more seasoning but it was fried nicely. Not too burnt not too soggy. Tender Rib Hand Pull Noodle: ok this is why I wait in line and why I am willing to drive hours. The broth is soo good. Boiled to perfection. The meat tender and lightly salted. The noodles have a nice bite and I love that they give you scissors. Just a great dish. And get this, $6-$9 range whaaat?! Pork Dumplings: the dumpling skin is lightly fried, the meat is juicy and with every bite comes some dumpling soup oozing out. Yum!I am a big self proclaimed noodle connoisseur and lemme tell ya, these hand pulled noodles hit the spot. Great Chinese comfort food. Price range is low so you can def pig out!

I ordered a Veg/Pork Noodles soup.. I was really disappointed compared to the last few times I went there. Noodles were barely boiled not the mention pork which I'm not even sure that it was pork, strange taste and texture. A total lack of vegetables and the broth was just ok.. It doesn't worth the price..

I had a few questions in mind when I went to this place. •_Is Mayan cuisine very different from standard Mexican-American cuisine? •_Even if so, would I be able to tell the difference? •_What color would my cheese be? •_Eating at Poc-Chuc didn't completely answer all of my questions, but it did tell me this: Mayan food can be freaking delicious.THE GIST: Fresh agua fresca / Excellent braised pork / Delicious corn tortillas / Good serviceSERVICE AND SETTINGI went here for a late dinner on a Saturday night. •_The restaurant wasn't very busy but had a few large parties and a number of diners eating alone; the latter may have been a hint of locals returning for a good meal. •_The restaurant quite clean and spacious for a place in SF.Service was very friendly and relatively quick. •_Our waiter was busy with the large party and took a long time to give us our check, but was very apologetic and even gave us dessert (a flan) on the house. •_Classy!FOOD AND VALUEChips and salsa: Served with a mild and a spicy salsa. •_The chips themselves are excellent. •_The spicy salsa creeped up on me on the first bite and should not be taken lightly.Agua fresca: I had mango and my friend had watermelon. •_Not an expert, but both were very flavorful and fresh.Rice and Corn Tortillas: Delicious. •_I believe they are both served with most of the entrees. •_I am usually not a fan of corn tortillas but the ones served here were amazing.Poc-Chuc (grilled pork): Probably my least favorite part of the meal, it was a little dry and didn't really stand out in any way for me. •_Disappointing, because it shares the name with the restaurant!Braised pork stew: The name of the dish escapes me and I cannot find it on the online menu... a shame, because it was my favorite part of the meal! •_Tender and tasty with a little bit of kick. •_I had a lot of fun eating it with the corn tortillas and rice.Flan: I don't usually order it and this one didn't really change that. •_However, it was given to us on the house and I must say, food is definitely more satisfying when it's free. •_Classy move on their part.The pricing escapes me, but I remember it being reasonable for a non-standard cuisine restaurant in SF.CONCLUSIONI'm not quite sure what the difference between Mayan and Mexican cuisine is, though I did notice there weren't any enchiladas or burritos on the menu. •_That being said, Poc-Chuc made me love Mayan food... whatever that is.
Waitress Olivia was nice. •_I feel like the food was lacking a little bit flavor-wise and portion-wise. •_Sometimes theres nothing better than non pretentious Mexican food. •_but i would return.

Good Luck no fiii stahs fo yoouu! •_I still love you and give you 4 though. •_I stopped by this weekend around 2:30 with barely any line, I waited for a minute to be served. •_This nice, but probably new lady (I haven't seen her before) helped me. •_We paid $15 for a feast. •_But when we got back home, I noticed we got gipped! •_They forgot 4 potstickers....grrr

This is the kind of taqueria where you order your food to go. •_It's the definition of hole-in-the-wall and judging strictly by appearances it's pretty grimey. •_If it didn't have so many rave reviews, I'd definitely be skeptical to eat here. •_But thankfully, I'm a yelper so I know to trust the fellow yelp community.Anyways, I'm not a big fan of sour cream but when I saw they put avocado in the super quesadilla I thought twice -- Avocado instead of Guac is deff my kinda place. •_Even if I don't love sour cream. •_Thank G I did. •_This huge quesadilla was bomb!! Oh and the salsa there is soo good, I'm salivating right now just thinking about how fresh and tasty their salsas are.Overall, a good taqueria I'd definitely go back but to ease my gag reflex I will continue to order to go!!

3 dishes you MUST order here:1. Geo Duck!!!2. Salted baked crab!!!3. Garlic noodles!!!You will NOT regret it! Oh soooo GOOD!SERVICE:SUPERB!! The owners are freaking awesome and super friendly! 5 stars!!

Second trip and will return!! HOWEVER!, the service from the wait staff sucks!! Last time (Dec 2011) the girl was a "Chola" (Latino gangster type) who did not come back, kept everyone in our section, the back of the bar, looking for her and asking others for things. Then when she did show up the drinks were wrong. This time 11/18, sat down for more than 20 minutes before being acknowledged, yet the bartender said hi. She then would never come back around and say "Oh it's crazy". The place is huge, and there were like 7 tables full out of 20 in the front section. I'd hate to see her full. She was not good. Food, Nachos and tacos, were good, drinks good, and the burger from Pete's Tavern next door, was great. They are the same owner and delivered while we sat inside Pedro's. Very nice. WIll be back and look for a third waitress.

I am a tequila snob. Padrecito knows this and takes very good care of me and my friends! Fine tequilas, AMAZING servers, and well, it is worth the wait (assuming you have to wait). I love Padrecito because they just take care of you. The servers are friendly and fun and just a delight to talk to. I go here at least once (twice) a week, and I drive up from the South Bay. Don't change a thing - well, ok, you can add a few more Tequilas. :-) •_Love you guys!

I live in Chicago, but I eat at Tommaso's at least once every time we visit San Francisco. It's small, but warm and cozy and friendly, and the food is outstanding. The lasagna melts in your mouth, the seafood is always fresh, and the wood-fired pizzas are phenomenal, with a perfectly chewy and delicious crust. No, they don't take reservations, and you'll probably have to wait for a table, but it's 100% worth the wait. I only wish I was in the bay area more often!

Overpriced, but definitely an interesting restaurant to check out, especially if you are ever in Westfield. The restaurant was very well-decorated. I ordered the Wild Boar Scissor Noodles, which was good! Add hot sauce and bam, the dish was pretty good. However, there wasn't enough "meat" either, especially in proportion to the onions and noodles. The noodles were fresh though and thick! $15 bucks - pricey, but try it at least once! I also ordered baby bok choy, which was very good! For $8, they gave a good portion. The vegetables were fresh, delicious and tasteful. I would definitely recommend ordering this side. As for customer service, our waiter was super attentive and attended our table pretty frequent

Yes, there's probably going to be a wait but even on a Saturday afternoon, we were happily grubbing on dim sum just under 15 minutes from when we got in line. Know what you want and don't be afraid to call it out as you get the attention of one of the ladies. The people behind us were astounded that we were on our way out after two minutes while they were still looking lost and clutching their cash. Being from Hawaii, I've been at a loss for good dim sum since I moved away. Needless to say, I snatched up some baked bbq and steamed bbq buns (known as manapua back home) as well as shu mai (pork hash) and some shrimp/scallion dumplings. Everything was amazing and fresh and hot. I didn't get a hot dog bun for old times sake as they were out but you gotta pace yourself. I popped into 3 other bakeries and dim sum places before leaving Chinatown and although I found what I was looking for, Good Mong Kok was the freshest.

Looking up at the changed sign, I drew a tear to see that it was Lichee Garden no more. •_Actually I didn't. •_For a more impactful beginning I thought I would just say that. •_Nonetheless, memories at the former Lichee Garden still vividly play through my mind. •_The biggest for me as a child, spelling "lychee", as "lichee", and not realizing the misspelling. •_Times have changed for this personal landmark. •_From the creators that brought you Hong Kong Lounge, a different lounge, Lai Hong Lounge has risen. •_Cue the Dark Knight Rises score. •_They must like using the word "lounge". •_After being flabbergasted, in the good way of course, by Hong Kong Lounge, I always wondered when Hong Kong Lounge would open a restaurant to challenge the likes of the dim sum of other SF Chinatown. •_Finally, it happened. •_This is it. •_Let it be known. •_There's a new challenger in town. •_Round one: Fight! •_ •_ •_ •_*Siu mai - Sometimes, you can't go wrong with a classic. •_Hong Kong Lounge steams up really good siu mai. •_Lai Hong has good ones too. •_No matter how you spell it, shu mai, siu mai, or just want to call it pork dumplings, you can't go wrong with them here. •_(I have a feeling I have written that last sentence in another review) •_If you didn't know already, yes, a touch of chili oil makes a siu mai 100% better.*Pan fried taro cakes - Unlike the thicker ones you'd usually see, they offer thinly layered taro cakes that are pan fried. •_These come out in a form reminiscent of a green onion pancake armored with a crispy texture. •_This will have anyone licking their chops for more (or licking the glistening grease from it). •_I don't think they have this in HK Lounge, but I could be wrong.*Chinese tamale, "zongzi" or "ZONG!" - Yes, Chinese tamale, share it. •_I doubt anyone can finish this $8 behemoth alone. •_This is a special item order. •_Inside the tamale is packed full of all kinds of ingredients from mung bean, Chinese sausage, and of course, that good o' slab of fat for extra flavor. •_Like any Chinese tamale, it's wrapped in leaves, Lai Hong's version are made for Yao Ming sized. •_It is prepared like the one at Hong Kong Lounge. •_So if you tried it there, similarities between the two are fairly noticeable. •_ •_ •_ •_ •_ As The Dark Knight Rises is arguably the second best movie in Christopher Nolan's Batman Trilogy, Lai Hong is also the distant second to Hong Kong Lounge. •_Quality levels are shades apart from HK Lounge. •_As a standalone unbiased restaurant, they shovel out good dim sum. •_While it has just opened not too long ago, they bring a strong competitor to the SF Chinatown options for dim sum.

Hands down best pizza in San francisco. We found this place through yelp. There is always crazy wait times here, I've been once told to wait for 2 hours! The key is to plan a meal here at an odd time, around 3 or 4 pm. We went at 4 pm and got a table instantly.The menu here is very detailed with temperatures for each pizza and the area where it's from. Even within Italy itself there are categories of specific locations from Italy!We got the one with arugula and one secret menu pizza that had caramelized onions, cheese and mushrooms on it. Both the pizzas were really good! The dough was fresh and thin, just like I want it.Their wine menu is also very nice, with Italian chianti, montepulciano wines which goes perfect with the pizzas.Will definitely come more often with visitors from outside Bay area and when we crave authentic Italian pizzas !

Best Chinese in the Mish, thats for sure.The food IS on/off from time to time, which I am ok with...because I only order for one thing:Fried Sesame Tofu (think Sesame Chicken without the nasty gristle or possibility of icky badly fried meat).This dish was served to me first by a boy I really liked. The boy was quickly gone, but my loyalty to Jasmine remained strong.It delivers pretty quickly, the thing I order is always amazing and delicious...and sometimes they even throw in a free hot and sour soup (which I also really like).My housemates have eaten some of the other stuff from here and say its either amazing one day or lackluster another...however I am personally always pleased.Overall, a decent joint to not be on the EC :)

There was a pretty big line at the El Faralito next to the Bart, so a group of us headed to this large empty taco joint. •_Cause an empty place next to a crowded place is probably pretty good, eh?The location is clean enough, the service friendly enough, and the menu had the right options. •_However, flavor wise everybody I was with agreed that the burritos at La Corneta didn't measure up the Mission's usual high standards. •_I think the flavor was a bit off, the proportion of veg to meat was a bit off.I don't think I'll be back.

Wow! I cant believe I just tried this place! This is awesome if you work in SoMa and need lunch! they decor is like route 66 with a bunch of cool memorabilia on the walls.Warning- this place is poppin during lunch time so best to head there closer to 11:30/11:45 than 12! The only way to explain the food is cali/mexi. CASH ONLY, but reasonably priced for lunch in SF. Expect to see the start-up/techies/nerds to fill this place up on their lunch break.You can easily get out of here with lunch for $10-12! Did I mention they also have an extensive list of beers on tap? The sodas are only served in the bottle! Loved it (and really added to their vintage vibe).Okay for food- I had the fried pork Zapto! What is a Zapato you may ask? Is is a burrito essentially, but filled with fries for your carb! I love that they Zapatos automatically come with guac... i hate paying extra for this little luxury (talking to YOU Chipotle!). Then they set it in a panini style grill to flatten/golden it!They also have this amazing orange sweet/spicy hot sauce that I have never heard of before!Not sure if they make it in house but it was amazing and had no label!The zapatos are definitely what you would want to order at lunch. Other items I saw that i would like to try next time are their assortment of fish tacos, and their ahi or crab burgers! I cant wait to come back!!!!
Exquisite. Alexis knows what he's talking about. They've got a real great culinary operation going on here. Time and time again - I'm in love
they are great , they are around for a long time .always smile at you .the super veg burrito is the best.

+ THE FOODThe food here is actually pretty decent but it's not the best dumplings or baos that I've ever had. After waiting for so long, my friends and I were excited to try their large XLB (the one that's so big you need a straw), but they were sold out!! We started with the shrimp toast, which is like a youtiao topped with a shrimp paste. I'm not sure if it was because we were starving, but we really enjoyed it. It was perfectly savory and the two different textures worked really well together. We also had their garlicky green beans which was very typical Chinese styled green beans, not all that special. Next came our pork bao that we requested to be pan fried. This was just a typical Chinese pork bun with lettuce and other vegetables. It wasn't all that special. We moved onto the two types of XLB- pork XLB and tom yum goong XLB. While both were filled with savory soups, we preferred the pork XLB over the tom yum goong XLB since it had less of a vinegry taste to it. The tom yum XLB wasn't spicy or sour like the soup usually is. Topped with meat and some ginger, the Beijing noodles were also pretty delicious, but it was definitely not enough to share for the 3 of us. We ended with the trio of happy ending buns- matcha and milk, egg yolk, and beet and taro bun. Of the 3 type of buns, the matcha and milk was our favorite, having a familiar custard-y, milky taste to it. - THE WAITDO NOT go on a weekend unless you know that are first in line. We arrived on a Saturday around 12:30 PM and we waited until 1:58 PM to be seated (it closes at 2:00 PM). Our food took a while to get out since there was still a lot of people waiting for their food. •_We were starving and cranky, making us feel that this trip to Dumpling Time wasn't worth it. - THE PRICESThe prices here are pretty steep, considering typical Chinese food isn't very expensive. However, this is more of an Americanized Chinese place and every plate is nearly $10 for just a few pieces. Although the food is pretty good, I felt that the wait and the prices weren't all worth it.

was excited about the opening of a fresh, organic mexican cafe in the neighborhood. •_stopped by on a sunday, craving a hard shell taco, but after eying the menu i found out they were $5/each-- and only soft shell. went with the veggie burrito. •_rice, pinto beans, avocado, veggies- lacked any spice/flavor. •_ most disappointing part of the meal were the salsas- completely bland with no heat! •_if the food isn't going to be well seasoned, they at least need to work on creating some flavorful salsas.
Great dim sum!!! Plus I'm really grateful I forgot my phone there and got it back!!! Thank you guys you made my day. INTEGRIY all the way
Good food, clean venue, but the service could be a little better. •_Definitely worth trying!

We came here for this first time a couple weeks ago. •_We were starving, craving pizza, and chose this place based on it's astronomical yelp status. •_A couple things of note: yes, as mentioned in almost every other review, this place is teeny tiny. •_We were lucky to get there when we did and snag a table. •_Still though, the tables are small and you're so close to the table next to you, it makes getting up awkward. •_Ok, now the reason for my 3-star rating: they brought our food to the wrong table. Ok, let me explain, normally this wouldn't upset me so much, but this restaurant is a TINY room with only 4 or 5 tables- how do you mix up the tables?? Worse, they gave our order to a couple who came in, sat down, and ordered probably 15 minutes after us. •_Again, the restaurant is super small, so we were keen on the fact that a table who had come in much later than us was eating before us, which is annoying in it's own right, and that they were eating what we had ordered. •_Then the waiter came up to us and said, "Sorry, there's been a mixup, we brought your food to the wrong table. We're starting your pizzas now." Ugh. •_So we wait another 15 minutes, starving (see above), watching a couple graze the pizzas we ordered.Ok so the pizzas themselves get 5/5 stars. •_Yes, amazing, delicious, mouth watering, unique pizza comparable to those in Italy. •_They are small though, and I would say, over-priced.Take away: Amazing pizza, though small portioned and over-priced. Sub-standard service. We will probably be back, but not dying to anytime soon. •_And we definitely wouldn't come during prime-time dining hours when it's sure to be busy.

We ordered 1 pound of geoduck sashimi and received 10 paper thin slices on ice that weighed 3-4 ounces. The taste was was fine but bland without ginger, wasabi or any other accoutrements . We were shocked at the tiny portion size but did not complain until the bill came for $50 including tax for one dish. When I asked about price I was told we ordered 1.5 pounds, not 1 pound at market price of $30/pound. I am open to the idea that the new immigrant waitress misunderstand our order but that would not explain the miniscule portion. I have dined out thousands of times, but this is the first I left no tip.

The next XLB in the city. We've been to all of the other places (I can't remember their names but I think they have Shanghai in their names). •_Dumpling Kitchen xlb's have the thinnest skin and are nice and soupy. Too bad this place is in the outer Richmond, or we'd be here every week!This place has huge portions too.
My bf brought me •_here once we started dating

A trendy spot to grab dinner. I didn't even know this row of restaurants existed in downtown until recently. I was able to easily make a reservation online a few days in advance for a Friday night at 7 p.m. I definitely recommend making reservations.
