Believe me when I say that this place is a legit hole in the wall. There's only approximately 10 seats at the counter, so you might have to wait at times. In spite of the cramped space though, Yamo seriously knows how to produce some delicious food. The women who work here know how to run this place efficiently, cost-effectively, and most importantly, deliciously. The food here is nice and incredibly flavorful (and oily). The tea leaf salad is a great starter. Although it's a little on the small side, it has great flavor and it's different from your typical tea leaf salad. My two favorite entrees are the Yamo House Noodles and the Mango Chicken. The noodles are very greasy and filled with tons of flavor and a light sauce. The meat is also always tender and cooked very well. The mango chicken also has tons of flavor, as there is nothing better than mixing the rice with the sauce and chicken. The chunks of fresh mango within the dish are generous and add a nice sweetness to the dish.Yes, you may not be getting the best service nor the cleanest services, but it all adds to the unique hole-in-the-wall-type vibe. It always amazes me to see how fast they are able to cook despite the lack of space and dim lighting. Even more, all the dishes here are no more than $6! (I think they actually recently bumped it up to $6.25....but still, it's a bargain!) What more could you ask for?! Don't be intimidated by its exterior (or interior for that matter...) appearance - this place serves great food at a great price!

The quality of the food is inconsistent. 4 stars when it is good though. But overall too inconsistent. The dishes I like from here are the Mapo Tofu, Chongqing Chicken Wings, and the Salt Cod Fried Rice. I almost never crave Chinese food but when I do, surprisingly it's this even though it's not "authentic" Chinese food. But over the past few years of eating here (mainly ordering for delivery), it's always a hit or miss. Sometimes it's delicious and spicy in a good numbing kinda way, and sometimes it's just bland. I ordered delivery last night and was disappointed. The chicken wings were way smaller than before, and it didn't have the crunchy tripe pieces. The tofu was spicy but bland. Very disappointing.

Their jjam bbong tasted like.... salt water. The large bowl came out piping hot, with all the right ingredients, smell and color. However, took one sip of the broth... and I thought, "wut?"It didn't have any depth in flavor whatsoever. No msg? But even so... come ON. what's going on here?I was sorely disappointed, and my spoon tasted and smelled like dishwashing detergent.I tried to pay with my debit card, and they said I couldn't use it unless my bill was over $20. I said I can go get some cash from an ATM. The lady said indignantly, "I'll take it this one time, but make sure you have cash next time."Ah yEEee Lady, there won't be nO NEXT TIME Okay. Again, another miss on Korean Chinese food in San Francisco.... smh

Well, for a Monday night this place was full at about 7:30 and rightly so. •_Our waiter, an authentic Italian gentleman had a great personality and was helpful. •_The service was also very Italian so don't expect to be up and out if you're eating here. •_Sit back and enjoy.As for the food I had the pasta in rabbit sauce. •_It was reasonably price, very good and filling. •_We also had a traditional bottle of Chianti, which was pretty standard.Finally they offered us some free limoncello and being that I'm part Jewish I LOVE free things, so we gladly accepted. Another cool thing about this restaurant it is feels cozy with cool little things all over the walls. •_I'll be back!

I had a delicious breakfast, I was there before the restaurant opened, you let me in the side door to use the restroom I waited for the current occupant to leave as they have one bathroom a man in employee came out of the bathroom and went downstairs under the restaurant that employee pissed all over the toilet seat !! What kind of brand asshole employee would piss on the only toilet seat in the restaurant it was pretty disgusting
They only have one vegetarian option, and it's nothing to write home about. In general, I find their food to be overpriced and over salted. I took another star off for mediocre guacamole.

Came here for brunch today after walking all the way to Naked Lunch just to find out it hadn't opened yet =/ I got the Garden Omelette and my friend got the Sausage and Gravy. Both our dishes looked so bright and fresh! He also got a huge cup of coffee that had free refills. I wasn't a fan of the cherry tomatoes inside the omelette. They exploded everywhere as I tried to cut into the omelette. The potatoes were amazing and I usually hate potatoes. I ate almost all the omelette without even realizing it! Haha. The toast that came with it was so strange tasting. Really chewy and bland. Their butter was also unsalted so I just salted it myself. Nothing worse than unsalted butter! Our waitress looked annoyed every time we asked her for something. She seriously gave me the most surprised look when I asked her for a straw. I'M SORRY THE ICE COLD WATER HURTS MY SENSITIVE GUMS. SHEESH. I would def come here again and avoid the waitress. There's just something about sitting indoors eating brunch on a rainy weekend morning =D

I have now been to Tacolicious twice and am a big fan. Good service, quick food arrival and - most importantly - delicious eats! •_The first time I went, I got a quick bite and it was just the tuna tostadas. They were really good and had nice kick to them. Last week, went for a mid-afternoon snack with friends and tried a bunch of stuff:-complimentary chips and salsa: excellent!-guacamole: excellent!-fried plantains: best I've ever had. I'm used to a sweeter, more caramelized fried plantains, but this was a more savory go of things. And loved that it was served with refried pinto beans.-tacos: we went with four. The butternut squash (decent), the braised short ribs (delicious); the chorizo and potato (decent); and the fried cod (great).I'll be back to try more of their menu - and have more plantains!

The food was great - I got the avocado taco, fish taco, and shishito peppers. They were all delicious! The bar staff was entertaining to watch and fairly attentive. My one complaint is that I found the hostess to be a bit unpleasant. I was a solo diner and wanted to use the restroom while I waited for a spot at the bar to open up (which was first come first serve and very very busy - I ended up waiting for an hour), but the hostess refused to keep an eye out for a seat for the 3 minutes it would've taken me to use the restroom cause she was too busy hostessing. I get that it's first come first serve... but it's a bit frustrating to think my hour long wait for a seat at the bar could've been extended to two hours if a seat opened up while I was in the restroom. If she had time to schmooze with customers throughout the restaurant for 2-3 minutes each (which she did a lot), she could've made the effort to help me not miss my chance at a seat. The first come first serve seating at the bar is also a poor system generally. It's sort of a matter of luck if you're standing close enough to the spots at the bar that open up. And some people sat at the bar for hours without eating... which would be fine if there weren't people who were waiting to sit. Just treat it as walk in seating for dinner, keep a waitlist, and separate people who want to just drink into an area that isn't possible seating for diners.
I used to order takeout from this place alot. It's pretty good Chinese food that preserves some of the authentic flavors and culture while nicely blending in flavors that suit American palettes

Badges? They don't wear no steenking badges here, senor!But if you've ever been to Oaxaca, you know there is a whole other side of Mexico that has nothing to do with sombreros, mariachi bands and those plastic dogs that have the heads that go up and down on your dashboard when you go low riding in the barrios. In fact, Regalito is exactly the type of clean, modern-looking place you'd find along a side street in Mexico's culinary capital.Make no mistake that in a neighborhood full of great south-of-the-border eateries, this one stands out for the fresh ingredients they use in some interesting variations on basic Mexican dishes. Standing out in its own building on 18th Street between Valencia and Lexington, the small, tidy place inside has a warm vibe with a bright chartreuse hue on the walls and stainless steel and beech wood on the lengthy counter.I ordered the $12.50 Pollo Con Mole Negro, which is a quarter-chicken, free-range of course, covered in a thick Oaxacan mole full of chiles, nuts, and spices. It came with stewed pinto beans and rice. Tasty and the breast-dominated chicken was cooked to the right tenderness. My friend had the simpler $9.50 Pollo Regalito, which is the leg and thigh of a chicken marinaded in garlic, lime and chiles. It also came with the beans and rice.Barely three months old, they also offer pork, steak and veggie dishes which I look forward to trying some other time. There are also a bevy of appetizers and side dishes of which we just ordered the $3 Salsa Fresca y Tostadas, a bowl of incredibly fresh tomato, onion and chile salsa with deep-dried tortilla rounds you need to break apart to scoop up the salsa. •_Yummy and just enough of a teaser for the entree.They even offer a $9.95 "Mexican worker's lunch" consisting of agua fresca, a chosen entree (today it was a pork dish), dessert or coffee. Sounds like a pretty good deal to me. The staff is friendly and incredibly quiet though not in a dysfunctional way since I am making the grand presumption that it is a family-run place.Keep in mind that it is small (just three tables and the counter), so I imagine weekend waits are a given. Even though you can have dessert here, just walk up 18th two blocks to get your scoop of salted caramel at the Bi-Rite Creamery.FOOD - 4 stars...fresh tasting...you feel you've made the healthier choice in the MissionAMBIANCE - 4 stars...clean, contemporary and no sombreros, serapes or velvet paintings of orphans on burrosSERVICE - 4 stars...very accommodating but no worries, they don't hoverTOTAL - 4 stars...has potential to earn another star if they get more daring on the dishes but fine and dandy for what it is

Cheap, mass produced dim sum that hits the spot for those looking for a quick meal. Great for take out.Ordered:Shrimp Har Gow - Texture is a bit jelly feeling due to being oversteamed, should be more fim. Shrimp taste is okay.Pork shiu mai - Large pieces, acceptable, reminds me of 99 ranch dim sum to go.steamed a bit too longBeef shiu mai - Also large pieces, got some of that beef flavor in it, bit oversteamed probably due to sitting around longer, not being as popular as the pork version.While I wouldn't be really looking for quality dim sum in a "to go" place, if you're nearby and want something fulfilling

Cute little Italian restaurant in SOMA. The menu isn't incredibly extensive, but just enough variety for you to choose from. The space feels intimate; dimly lit with candles and soft overhead lighting. I especially like the brick and arches that make up the space. They also have photos and paintings on the walls that can be purchased from local artists. The service here is also top notch. Expect the waiters to be extremely friendly and doting.Now, onto the food. I always like to start with the burratta which they serve with prosciutto, arugula, and this balsamic sauce. My favorite dishes are the lamb ragu, the frutti de mare, and their lobster ravioli. Their saffron risotto leaves something to be desired. Entrees are approximately $17 each. Dinner for four will probably run you $30 a person including wine and appetizer to share.

Was looking for some new places to go to in the Excelsior and found this on Yelp. •_My super shrimp burrito was pretty yummy... had some sort of rich creamy flavor I'm not used to. •_Green salsa from the bar was excellent. •_Atmosphere is nice... bright and clean and has TV screens. •_I'll definitely go back.
I've been there several times and the food was amazing all the time! It has the best hot

I wish there was a worse rating than 1 star. •_Mijita restaraunt is the type of restaraunt that introduced me to Yelp last year. •_When you have such a terrible experience and feel so ripped off you want to scream it from the mountain tops to save one of your fellow diners the dissapointment of a terrible and expensive meal and not to mention waste of time.Mijita's is HORRIBLY overpriced. •_The food is VERY greasy and quite frankly they lie on their menu.For your information Mijita...those tacos you served me are called taquitos! •_If its rolled like a taquito, fried like a taquito, only has meat entombed into the middle of the fried taquito then its a taquito..not a TACO. •_While $7.95 may sound decent for an order of 3 tacos it is not decent for cold, over fried, disgusting TAQUITOS! •_The Chips and Salsa. Well the salsa was okay. I only ate one chip and had a greasy face for the rest of day. •_Here is the worst part..for 2 plates (6) of taquitos, chips and salsa, 1 bottle of water and 2 drinks...$30!!!!!! This place is awful and I will NEVER go back.

People who gave Emmy's a 4 or 5 star rating have not had good Chinese food. I don't get it. I've never dined in, but as a new Excelsior resident, I've been trying to find good Chinese delivery (Bamboo on Polk used to be my go-to for Chinese, but that was back when I lived in the Mission). I've ordered a couple of times and didn't really think too highly of it, but by the third time, I decided it was enough. They do the bare minimum with their vegetable dishes, and the two I ordered were Garlic Sauteed Spinach and Garlic Sauteed Broccoli. They both were VERY watery and lacking any flavor beyond garlic. There were literally big chunks of it with the wateriness of the steamed (or satuteed or whatever) vegetables, and that was it. No more! No sauce, no char, no nothing spectacular or noteworthy. BARE MINIMUM. And did I mention the wateriness???Side note: The sauteed spinach was so slimy and watery that I found it difficult to eat. So... I didn't eat it! But I did use it in spinach alfredo over fusilli the next day. If I had to re-purpose food from Emmy's, then that's saying something!!The other vegetable dish I ordered was alright. Three stars maybe. It was the Spicy String Beans (or something like that), and again, this dish lacked any flavor beyond spice. And yeah, I know that's what the name entails, but if I have to throw it into a pan and add more chili flakes, sesame oil, garlic, and soy sauce in order for me to want to eat it and get my money's worth, then what was the point of even ordering delivery in the first place??I also tried their Singapore Rice Noodles. Soooo good... USUALLY. The Singapore Rice Noodles at Emmy's were alright actually. Not bad even! Just that they didn't mix the curry very well so some bites were way more saltier than others, but again, not bad at all really.Lastly, the epic fail: Chow Fun. I got it with the sauce on the side. It was really bland and flavorless. A real let down to be honest. I'm from Hawaii and maybe the Chow Fun is different? (Yes, I think it is drier and saltier and mixed with char siu). But since moving to SF, I have found it difficult to find really good tasting chow fun. So who knows, maybe I have high standards and the chow fun at Emmy's isn't all that bad. BUT, let me just say for the record... I didn't eat more than four bites of it. I tried to like it, but.... No. Doesn't work that way. Into the trash it went, and for that, I got angry at myself for wasting yet more money ordering lackluster crap from Emmy's!!!Well I hope that's helpful. I am a vegetarian, so maybe their meat dishes are their best sellers? Basically their dishes are very bland and bare minimum-esque... That's my main critique.
im Sum Restaurant|

I loveeee Dos Pinas! They are very close to where I work, and we eat there from time to time. There burritos and nachos are Delish! I was even more impressed when we ordered food for 100 people from Dos Pinas through Mission Bay Catering. The food was absolutely perfect for our pre-wedding Picnic. I can't recommend them enough!!

Scala's food wasn't bad but it wasn't memorable either. •_The location is great, in a hotel and close by Union Square. •_Staff was well trained and polite. •_Atmosphere was great. •_I would likely come back and try something else. •_If you bring your own bottle of wine, they did have a nominal corkage fee.

This is a fun place to go for trivia on the first thursday of every month- be ready for some stiff drinks and even stiffer competition. •_The food is pretty good, but after a couple sips of their rockin' margaritas you'll forget why you care.

This place is getting worse and worse. •_They used to have big portion of shrimp dumplings, but not anymore. •_Plus they have increased some of their prices. •_Ordered lobster noodle last time and they didn't even give you a full lobster. •_Such a rip off. •_For the past few times, there was lesser wait time and I guess many people dislike this place now.

5 STARS - Baby!Great food and great people that run this place...looking forward to their opening. •_Jasmine Tea House will be opening after the new year 2012. •_I spoke with one of the owners today 12/18...He said that they'd be opening sometime after the new years. •_I actually stepped inside the place and spoke with Robert. •_Very nice and cordial owners.The Jasmine Tea House neon sign was lit up too!Look for them to open soon!

San Diego, my girlfriend tells me, is unlike anywhere else when it comes to Mexican food. While visitors from all over the U.S. are a little shocked at the size of "California burritos" - burritos with sour cream, guac, and, good heavens, RICE - I was agape the first time I saw carne asada fries at Taqueria Los Coyotes, and the similar burrito.I'm not going to act the fool by comparing this to other taquerias because you really can't. Not on the basis of the carne asada fries burrito, anyway, since that's pretty uncommon for Northern California. •_I will say this, though: the concept is genius. Here you have a taqueria at the end of a street filled with bars, that's open late, cheap, serves comfort food and is the last thing between you and BART/MUNI/where the cabs pick up. Of course it's going to make money! The burrito was pretty ok, but after a night of drinking and dancing it was just what I needed. Not all comfort food has a positive additive effect when combined - pickles and ice cream only works if you're really high or really pregnant - but I can safely say that fries and burritos hit the spot. Would I go here for lunch, given the selection nearby? No, probably not. But Taqueria Los Coyotes has a niche and fills it quite well.

Okay I'll admit I've only ever had five dishes from here, but I LOVE everyone (and I get stuck in a dishes I love rut with asian food but thats my choice and don't disregard my review because of it).Their General Tsou's Chicken is divine. •_Not goopy sweet or ridiculously spicey like most places. •_That perfect balance of sweet and spicey and perfect with plain white rice. •_Their Shrimp and Snow Peas is also amazing. •_Simple, light but super flavorful. •_This girl loves her snow peas and devours every one. •_I've also had the potstickers and pork fried rice, good staples that you can't go wrong with. •_The potstickers have a nice firm skin and aren't a soggy mess and the pork fried rice is light and not greasy like a lot of places.
Great pupusas, cheap prices, and as much pickled cabbage and salsa as you need. The plantains were also delicious. Their mushroom and garlic pupusa is definitely my favorite!
exican Kitchen|

A welcomed addition to Cole Valley!Occupying the former location of EOS, Padrecito offers an energetic vibe along with good food. •_It's welcoming to a diverse crowd, both young and old as well as for singles, couples, large groups, and families. •_The large windows and balcony seating provide a very spacious and airy feeling. •_With reservations, we were seated promptly in the balcony area and the service throughout the meal was attentive.Some of the dishes we had were:* Crudo - Bite-sized pieces of yellowtail served in a guacamole style dip of mango, avocado, and a chipotle-agave salsa, accompanied with blue corn strips. •_The mixture was a little heavy that you couldn't taste the true flavor of the yellowtail.* Quesadilla Entemporada - A generous combination of asparagus, chentrelle mushrooms, green garlic, and jack cheese melted between a large flour tortilla, and which can be topped with a tasty salsa.* Ensalada Fresca - A refreshing salad of jicama, chicories, kumquats, spiced pepitas (pumpkin seeds), and cotija cheese drizzled with a lime-agave vinaigrette dressing. •_A good prelude to the main dishes.* Chipotle Chilaquiles - Tortilla chips mixed with duck carnitas, kale, fava beans, spring onions, chipotle mole, and a spicy crema. •_I couldn't really taste the duck but after eating this a while, you really feel the fire!and last but most definitely not least* Crispy Local Calamari Tacos - •_Superb slightly crispy corn tortillas topped with a well-seasoned garlic aioli, perfectly deep fried calamari, and a chipotle-chayote slaw. •_Delicious!* Mango Chile with Mascarpone Popsicle - A very enjoyable way to end your meal. •_Not only a unique but also a very refreshing dessert option! •_The level of spice in the mango chile was perfect and not overpowering, and the mascarpone was smooth and creamy. •_It's very similar to your old-time 50-50 bar but much better! •_Perfection!I would have to say their tacos are the real winners and they offer a wide selection. •_The prices are reasonable, with all dishes under $20. •_Parking in the area can be difficult so I would recommend public transportation (N Judah) which stops right in front!Thank you Padrecito for an enjoyable meal and welcome to Cole Valley!

This place is rocking every minute they are open. •_I ordered from the catering menu. •_Pick up was so smooth, I could have skated. •_Terri and group are friendly and pay close attention to detail. •_They called with questions to confirm the order. •_The food....OUT OF THIS WORLD. •_Serioulsy $300 and fed a group of 30 with leftovers. •_Packaging was perfect too.

Food is fantastic, but the lady at the table next to is with her shoes on the floor and her bare feet on the chair is disgusting. I'mSurprised none of the staff hasn't said something. It's a bit distasteful... About the food! Delicious, fresh and always great! I love their salads... Giant... Filling and they melt in your mouth. Their staff is phenomenal, kind and helpful.

I was having dinner with girlfriends in the Marina and Delarosa popped up on Yelp as a great option. I saw on the website that the team behind Delarosa has connections to Beretta (amongst other restaurants) - I love Beretta and was excited to try Delarosa. Delarosa was great and I would definitely go back. The bar is a great spot to post up while you're waiting for friends or to dine with another friend. We were there on a Monday night and we were able to get a table quickly at 7:30. The big windows give it an open and airy feeling, and there are a few tables outside for those rare warm SF evenings. Most of the tables inside are communal and by the time we finished dinner (around 9:30), the music had been turned up to levels that made it tough to converse. The following is how I would rank the dishes we ordered: - Crispy taglioni dumplings: imagine a cheese and prosciutto-filled dumpling deep-fried and sitting in marinara sauce. So good, so gooey.- Mushroom pizza: great pizza dough - I normally don't eat crust but this was an exception. - Crab arancini: yes, more deep-fried food and this was also cheesy and delicious but maybe not the best I've ever had- Panzanella salad: great flavored with the fennel croutons but the tomatoes were a bit too soft / over-ripe and didn't hold up well in the salad
It's been good for a long time. Very consistent for delivery-fast

It is a typical foodie place. The dishes are well-prepared and presented. Servers are very attentive. We had both golden caviar and white truffle options. The truffle was in season and smelt exceptional. The dishes were small but we were full when we left. They gave us a warm chocolate on the way out which was a nice touch with the cold weather. Nothing against Quince. It seems that Michelin star restaurants treat food more like an art form than food itself. Something is lost here.

I love the food here but the service can be hit or miss at times and not dependent on the rush (or lack thereof). They are very generous with the chips and salsa and have a great imported beer selection. I highly recommend the mole poblano and the fajitas. Margaritas are decent. The dê©cor is really fun and reminiscent of a restaurant in Guadalajara I visited. When the wait is long, you can go next door and have a drink while waiting and they'll come get you. Great neighborhood spot.

This place was outstanding! As out-of-towners, my husband and I decided to risk it and try to sneak in a table at Tony's on a Saturday night. When we arrived, our hostess told us it would be a two and a half hour wait, but the bar area is first come, first serve. Tip: Wait by the bar! Something WILL come open! A wonderful older couple saw us patiently waiting and gave us their seats within 30 minutes of us getting to the restaurant. (I saw everyone that waited for a seat get a seat by the end of our visit.) The couple next to us got the New Yorker pizza, which looked and smelled like the most heavenly pizza known to man. We ordered a glass of IPA, a glass of Cab wine, three meatballs, and the New Yorker- all so delicious. The New Yorker has the best sausage/pepperoni combination I've had. Its huge- my husband and I couldn't finish it together. I would highly recommend it! Our bar service was outstanding and helped to make the experience great. We will be back to Tony's when we return to San Francisco.

Overpriced and overrated.The marinara sauce was watery and flavorless except for a hint of sweetness. The bread was like styrofoam. The service was less than friendly except when the check came, which by the way was $32.00...for 1 person, a dinner salad, a small bowl of spaghetti and a glass of wine..

Looking for something outside of the usual pho establishments in the Tenderloin? Look no further - Hai Ky Noodle shop is right around the corner specializing in teochew noodles. This noodle shop has been around since 1987 serving Chinese styled broths. But we're all here for one reason and that is the braised duck noodle soup. I can't imagine how many ducks these chefs are braising out in the back, but practically everyone in the restaurant has made an order of this delicious soup. The noodles are SO very flavorful and the duck is not fat and the meat falls right off the skin unlike in most Thai or Chinese noodle soups. •_Note that I would definitely recomnend the thick egg noodle! Overall, I would highly recommend the restaurant when you're in the mood for a Chinese style broth, fast service and great pricing!

Love this place! Quality food and ingredients for the price. One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city. I don't live anywhere near this place but make a special trip over when I'm craving tasty Chinese.

Ok I should have known not to sit in the bar for Sunday brunch but 2 seats were open by the window and it wasn't that loud, like usual, so we sat there. •_I should have asked about the menu because i found out too late the dining room serves a full menu at lunch. but the bar just has a bar brunch menu. •_I ordered the crabcake eggs benedict and when it finally arrived everything on the plate was cold •_the eggs were cold and not poached very well, the potatoes were cold, the coffe was luckewarm and when I realized that the kitchen forgot the english muffices under the crabcakes the waitress said she would get me some from the ditchen...by the time they got me the muffins I had eaten everything anyway...very dissapointing. •_but please understand that I really like this place , I will just never sit in the bar again.

This is a hybrid korean-chinese restaurant that my wife craves everytime we go up to the bay area... Hence the name So, they close when they want without notice, that's an awesome business model...haha.On to the food.We had the curry fried rice-it's ok, Thai people make it better..lolFried chickenFried beefFried calamariAll taste like fried meat with white pepper, but I still think the fried beef is the way to go!

A16 is back to hitting on all cylinders. •_Great service. •_An up-tempo venue. •_And of course really good food.I started with a terrine of rabbit and duck that came with plums and blackberry honey. •_The grainy terrine was perfectly complemented by the stone fruit and honey. •_A well-sized half order of fregula with corn, fava beans and mascarpone was lovely. •_Not too much cheese. •_Perfect, sweet corn in abundance. •_And likewise the favas.Finally, a berkshire pork chop with peach mostarda and toasted hazelnuts. •_The large rim of fat around the chop sealed the meat so that it remained very moist. •_The mostarda was wonderful and could have stood on its own as a not too sweet desert.All in all a great meal.

Overall this was a miss for me. •_Too much cheese, not enough fresh, bright flavors. •_My vegetarian main of the poblano pepper was pretty bland. •_It's adorable inside, and people were happy and all that. •_But breaking down to the food it just wasn't there for me.Maybe the big issue is trying to make TexMex in a land of Mexican. •_Like walking into a Kobe beef steak house and asking for a Whopper. •_Driving past a Four Seasons to go to a Motel 6. •_Passing up a Cadillac for a Pinto. •_I'd come in again for drinks, and then head to a proper Mexican place to chow down.

This place is amazing - most of the time I struggle with Chinese places I visit because I can't forget the taste of food from actual Chinese joints from China. This place not only comes close in their traditional department, it improves with new amazing combinations. There is quite a line in front of it, but it's definitely a place to go to!

Nice spot for some drinks and dinner.. definitely make a reservation in advance! It is a bit on the pricier side but some of the dishes were just really outstanding! I can't remember which cocktails I ordered, a peach something, but really tasty but not stiff.Crispy Duck Salad - holy moly, who would've thought a salad could be so good? This is a definite must if you're dining here. Super light, super flavorful. The duck wasn't too gamey, all the ingredients complemented each other well.Dim Sum Platter - good. I know it's just dim sum but you can tell that the quality and size of each item was better than your average dimsum from a cart. Truffle Braised Noodles with Crab and Scallops - I don't even care that much for truffle but holy moly, these noodles were tasty! The truffle went surprisingly well with the noodles. The scallops were cooked perfectly. I definitely recommend this!Stir Fried Black Pepper Beef - super tender and super delicious.Spicy Prawns - huge! It was so good but by the end of the meal I was getting really full and couldn't eat more than one prawn. The curry was really delicious though, and the prawn was very fresh. I loved this dish as wellDessert - I'm not too sure, I completely forgot what it was called but I know it was something with Kombucha.. but really good. Texture was great and not too sweet.Macarons - I'm not a huge macaron gal but these were really good! And large! Everything here was pretty fantastic and would definitely come back just for that duck salad! It was just too yummy!

Place is well known for crab. It feels like every time my mother in law is town she's always asking for that Vietnamese crab in the tenderloin. The crab is definitely 4.5 stars. Tasty and baked with fried garlic and jalapeê±os. I can't really tell if it's baked or fried. It tastes a little more fried and is pretty biteable with your teeth ( not that I'm recommending that- they totally supply utensils to crack the crab). The outside flavor is great but it feels a little bit like the crab meat inside is a little extra stringy through this cooking process. We got a hot and sour soup (Vietnamese style with chicken) - definitely 5 stars. It's very different from the more regular hot and sour soup at chinese/ asian places. It was more of a clear sour broth with chicken and vegetables. It's definitely my favorite dish I've had at the restaurant. As for the pea shoots, pan fried crispy noodles, and black bean filet dishes we also got - they were completely average, and a little on the bland side. I kept adding the crab's garlic and jalapeê±os to those dishes. Overall - come for the crab (when it's more in season otherwise it's $$$$), and surprise fantastic dish is the Vietnamese hot and sour soup.

Bar was PACKED on Cinco De Mayo. The food looked like it was a good portion. I didn't sit down to eat because there were no seats available, so to the bar it was!Margaritas were $7, but you can also buy a pitcher, which serves 4-5 people for ~$26. It was more than enough to give 6 of us drinks. Perfecto! I was planning to bar hop anyway, so we got a couple of drinks of margaritas and bounced.The floors were sticky when we went there, probably because people had been drinking the entire time. The only drawback I would have is that there was no announcement as to how to get a table to eat. I came with a group of 8ish people, and we didn't know we had to find the man sitting in the corner to put our name on the list. At least announce it, put it on the door, or have someone standing there directing people! Understandable, it was chaotic, but being in the Mission -- a restaurant should be prepared!

Love coming to Tropisueno when I'm in town. Their Happy Hour eats and drinks are on par for sure! It's down this lovely corridor with some nice restaurants attached to the Marriott. I enjoy the fact that it has patio seating in addition to indoor. Makes for awesome people watching!$6.50 house margarita and some $7 nachos that can feed 3 people and you're set! Add $2 for some meat on those and I'm in heaven. Their carnitas are flavorful and tender. Free chips and salsa as always. I enjoy that they have 3 different salsas on one plate. All taste great and love the spicy habanero one! Prices are fair which makes me happy considering San Fran prices can be expensive. Staff here are always nice but wait times and service can tend to be slow around HH and dinner rushes no matter what day it is. If you're coming to have a conversation, certainly don't sit in the bar. It is super noisy and the bartenders have a hard time hearing your order. All in all though the food is consistently good and is a nice spot to grab some decent Mexican food.

I'm always on a quest to find a meal that will blow me away. I have no idea what took me so long to stop by SPQR but late better than never, right? We were a group of four so we ordered a good amount of dishes across the menu. Everything we had was good but their pasta blew all of us away.Smoked Fettuccini was my fave. The Lobster Tortelli and the White Corn Ravioli •_were equally as good. Buckwheat Tagliatelle was good but it was our least fave out of the four pastas. I can honestly say, it's the best pasta I've tasted thus far. I thought Flour + Water was pretty awesome but this blows them out of the water. =)Service was great as well. My only gripe is that the place is pretty small, so tables are pretty tight.SPQR is my new standard for pasta.

Checked out the new neighborhood spot and I am pleasantly surprised! A great cheap spot for a fast eat. A fusion between Mexican and Korean street food... It all makes sense now ...TACO + KOREA = TACOREA!!! •_Had the kimchi burrito and it was bomb! The meat was excellently seasoned and they serve a pretty big burrito. I definitely need to try out more on the menuTry the green salsa it is AMAZING!

The food was lovely. We shared a chips dish that had hot sauce on it, and I had Rajas con Crema.However, the service was lacking .... I blame the runners, although the waiter was in charge and should have been on the ball. The waiter didn't note down the diners' seating position so the runner was standing there, asking who got what.At those prices that doesn't fly!!
Chicken super burrito is my go to! I come multiple times per week, and it's amazing every single time! The carne asada is also good here!

I wandered into Fang as a recommendation of my brother who frequents San Francisco often. I was on my way to their other restaurant House of Nan King, which is an all time favorite when Mike said to give Fang a try. I'm happy to proclaim I am now a fan of Fang as well! Peter (the owner) saddled up to our table to wait on us. Upon hearing that we are fans of Nan King, he smiled and quickly grabbed the menus from us. How do you turn down being personally waited on by Peter the Great? Especially after he announced he "would take care of us". Such a nice man, obviously very proud of his restaurant, as he should be! The dishes started arriving, perfectly timed. We sampled some fabu dishes including a duck bun, crispy shrimp with apple, mushroom fried rice and a sauteed fish and greens. Don't ask me what the names were as most of the items weren't on the menu and rang up as misc items. All i can say is if you are in the area DEFINITELY head to Fang or House of Nan King. You wont be disappointed! If you are lucky Peter may wait on you as well!

Worst customer service in the world! All the servers have major attitude and one actually CUT US OFF mid sentence when we were requesting her to help cut a dim sum dish (which is standard practice). To top it off, the food was terrible, greasy, and flavorless AND they auto-charge 15% gratuity LOL we actually laughed in the waiter's face. Plenty of other dim sum establishments where I'd rather spend my money than this place. Don't be fooled by Obama's visit!

What a gem! Stumbled across this place one night after an afternoon at land's end. The margaritas are strong and yummy and the food is huge and delicious. I just wish it was more convenient! I rarely end up that far out on Clement, but when I do it's a treat.

I thought it was just okay. I liked the atmosphere - it was cozy and intimate - but the food was so-so. My friend I shared a warm seafood salad to start. The portion was larger than I expected, and some parts were really good, but the mussels tasted undercooked and fishy. I got a the seafood lasagna for the main course. It wasn't what I expected, but it would've still been a solid dish if it wasn't so salty. I couldn't stop drinking water the whole time because all the salt made me so thirsty.

Was referred this place by a friend who lives in the city and this is for sure a hidden gem. Very authentic Italian food. Amazing service and good portion size. Everything was delicious. Had the caprese and bruschetta for an appetizer and was not disappointed. The meatballs were also fantastic. Would highly recommend.

Nice place. Delicious steaks! The 10oz Flank steak was great - and way (I mean WAY) more than 10oz. Cobb salad was great. So was service. Maybe the (good piano jazz) music was a wee bit on the loud side - but hey, maybe it's just me? It certainly wasn't a problem! We'll be back.

PROS: quality food, tasty soup base, many options for dipping sauce, attentive service, good value CONS: very long wait without reservation, condensation on low ceiling from hotpot that drips down on you (ewwww). They really need to do something about this because the ickiness of this is a deal breaker for most people

Parking here is difficult to find so you may need to circle around the block a couple of times.I came here with a friend because we were given the impression that there was 50 cents margarita. Turned out that they "never" had it, as told by a server.I ordered Nick's Way. At first, I was overwhelmed with my food because it was huge. I had to crunch it up to be able to eat it and it tasted mediocre.Not only was their food mediocre, but their servers weren't that attentive. Waited 10 minutes for one just to get a refill and another to get our check.Would not go back to this place.

This place is overrated and overly priced. I'm not sure why it became a michelin starred restaurant. The food is so salty, lost the original taste of the food, especially when you say you are a Chinese restaurant. If you claim that you are a typical American Chinese restaurant, that might be acceptable. Then in their wine selection, they did not include any Chinese wines. Not a choice at all. BUT they have Japanese wines? What are you a Chinese or a Japanese restaurant excuse me? Oh then it comes to the service. I'm not sure about the server's condition that day, maybe she just broke up with her boyfriend. The attitude was so bad that she almost hit the table with the water bottle. And if you would like explain to me that the display of the food is great, I would totally disagree with you. The food display is as standard as the fine dining in any western styled restaurant at the most, and not even close to any fine dining Chinese restaurant. I highly recommend the critics of Michelin to revisit their SF location and reconsider their ratings. What a disappointment. If I could, I would like to seek for a refund from their restaurant.
pancake was too friedlamb skewer was oknoodle soup was good

While I've eaten at Perbacco multiple times (and enjoyed the food and experience), this review is for private dining I have booked with Stephen Lee. •_Stephen is consistently prompt, professional, and pleasant. •_He has been very helpful with finding a date that works for my party, even when it was somewhat of a moving target, as well as answering all of my questions and offering helpful suggestions.

My father took me here when I was a kid and always loved the place.I used to recommend this place as the best burrito in town but sadly report that this was one of the worst burrito I have eaten. My partner and I took a bite of our burritos and it was really bland and I had to drench it with sauce. The meat was cold and no flavor. Que Paso raza I am really disappointed and feel cheated. They seem they forgot to cook. Some many choices in San Francisco sorry me no come again!

Was really excited to try this place, but had a choppy experience here. •_Made a 7:15 reservation and showed up ten minutes early for it, but wasn't seated until 7:45 because they were running behind. •_The hostess was very gracious about it and warm, aside from being hungry, we weren't in any kind of rush - so it was a disappointing sign, but not the end of the world.We got seated at a nice table in the end, and the overall decor and ambiance was great! •_Everything from here on out was a very mixed bag.Guacamole: OKFundido: SolidCeviche Sampler: The pescado one was great, the oyster and crab ones were pretty bland and seemed to have a lot of fillerPistachio Fish, at the waiter's suggestion: Extremely blandCinnamon donuts: Outrageously goodSalted caramel ice cream: See aboveBecause of the long and unexpected wait for the table, the hostess said they would take a discount off our final bill, which they did not do - not holding their word was a bit disappointing.Overall, the restaurant had several ups and downs - there's promise here, so I might go give it another shot, but I did find the overall experience a bit disappointing and not quite worthy of the coin.

Enjoyed my birthday dinner here when my boyfriend treated me out.We asked for complimentary bread because we read about it on Yelp, but they don't seem to give it to you unless you ask. Make sure you ask if you want it! The bread was soft, and I loved the sun-dried tomato dipping oil. Just wished that the bread was warm because it was cold when we got it :( Still good, but could've been great if they warmed up the bread.I love bone marrow, so we ordered that as an appetizer. The bone marrow by itself was on the salty side a little more so than the usual, but eaten with the bread and parsley salad, it was great. Super rich and buttery like good bone marrow shouldbe.At this point, our server randomly gave us two pieces of bruschetta on the house. Nothing spectacular, but hey it was free! An unexpected small treat.For entrees, we ordered the smoked salmon tagliolini with black caviar (Tagliolini Salmone) and the squid ink spaghetti with seafood (Frutti Mar). I LOVED the squid ink spaghetti. Great amount of seafood, PERFECTLY cooked al dente pasta, and the tomato sauce was so good that I started eating it by the spoonful by itself towards the end. The smoked salmon pasta was more subtle. The pasta sauce was a little bland by itself, unless you got a bite with the smoked salmon or caviar. It was good, but I ended up wishing that there was more smoked salmon (even though they didn't necessarily skimp), just to make every bite as good as the ones with the salmon.We ordered the panna cotta for dessert, as per Yelper recommendation. They put a little candle in it for my birthday and also gave us two mini glasses of dessert wine to go with it--Another unexpected treat on the house. The panna cotta was creamy yet light, and it went well with the tartness of the berries. Didn't think it was as amazing as others made it to be, but still good.Overall, the stars of our meal were the bone marrow and squid ink spaghetti with seafood, plus the great service with unexpected items on the house. Well-deserving of 4 stars.
Cioppino was the best i have ever eaten anywhere. •_The broth was the key to the flavor. Five stars.The oysters were great, Both East Coast

West of Pecos was recommended to me by a coworker, so I headed there on a Tuesday night to grab some dinner and drinks. My boyfriend and I both had a spicy margarita - mine with mezcal (Mohave) and his with just tequila (la flama verde). Both were delicious! We also had the queso dip with chorizo to start. For our main corse we had puffy tacos, one crispy carnitas and one bbq beef brisket. I preferred the carnitas! We also had fish tacos which were pretty good. I love the vibe of this restaurant and I will definitely come back!
Loved the aesthetic of this place

Stopped by here to grab some pizza, and it was GREAT. The crust is amazing: ultra thing, crispy, everything you could want really. The sauce is sweet, fresh, and there's lots of it!The atmosphere was pretty cool too. The owners seem to speak nothing but Italian. They were serving Sangria and Cranberry juice, which I •_thought was funny.Good stuff.

Not the best. Takes for EVER to get your order and they frequently mess up simple requests. Nice and clean and close to home. GF likes the chorizo burrito so I keep coming here but definitely not better than Street Taco on Haight (or even Lil Chihuahua if you don't want to leave the Divis corridor) or most taquerias in the Mission for that matter. Again, excellent Mexican food North of Geary seems hard to come by these days but maybe I'm just picky. They seem busy enough and won't go out of business anytime soon. Register clerk is super sweet, usually, but some staff are not as welcoming. Maybe they're stressed, who knows, but I really don't want to deal with 'tude when I'm hungry and waiting. Place is nice after remodel and has two flat screen TV's playing sports, but I gotta say, if they were three blocks further from my house I'd say f@k it. Fyi, wrote entire review while waiting for my latest order (after walking next door for a six pack mind you) and still like three orders in front of me

My cousin works here and I came to visit. This place •_is beautiful. The service is great. And the food is amazing. One thing I recommend is getting reservations because it gets really busy at night. During the day it is not as much. I loved the ceviche and the carnitas. And the caipirinhas are great too!

This Korean Chinese restaurant is probably considered decent for SF standards. •_Just to clarify, this is NOT a traditional Chinese restaurant. •_There's a separate category for these kinds of places and should be logged under Korean Chinese cuisine. That is why they serve Kimchi. Usually, it's not the usual Korean kimchi. •_The twist is, that they don't use napa cabbage but the green one.We had the jellyfish, •_sweet and spicy beef (tangsooyook), clams in black bean sauce, •_San Wang fried rice, sizzling rice soup and spicy shrimp (kkanpoong shrimp). All the dishes were underseasoned. •_They could've used some salt. If they had, •_the meal would've probably been much better. •_ At least it wasn't salty, •_I suppose. The clams in black bean sauce tasted different than the usual ones you get at Chinese restaurants. maybe this is supposed to have a Korean twist? It tasted like some sauce with gochujang (red pepper paste) in it.

Let me start to say - I love Perbacco, and that is why writing this review is difficult to write.I often bring work colleagues and clients for lunch to Perbacco - the food is consistently amazing and the service discrete but attentive.I took 4 people for lunch today and had a wonderful lunch - at the end of the meal we all surprisingly decided to go for a glass of port. I ordered the table 4 glasses of Tawny Port 20 years old ($20 per glass), this took over 20 minutes to arrive at the table which was surprising as our table was next to the bar and we were one of the few tables still occupied in the restaurant. One of guests who loves port commented it was not a 20 year port but much younger - as I'm not a port expert I thought I'd ask to see the bottle to show my guest. I asked our waiter if he could bring us the bottle and some 20minutes later he appeared with an empty port bottle - a 20 year Tawny port. I asked why it took so long to reach over the bar and how come it was empty - there was no response. The bottle had been washed out so I could not show my guest that what we were drinking was really a Tawny 20, and the restaurant had no other bottles.........it all seemed very fishy and we all felt we had been served a sub-standard drink and not what we had ordered. This may all sound snobbish but at $20 a glass I think a wonderful restaurant of this caliber could have managed this situation far better...... I left with a $340 bill feeling like I'd been ripped off and taken advantage of. Will I return? Sadly I feel the spell of Perbacco has been broken......UPDATE*******i received a call from the owner - a lovely gentleman - who explained the mix up with the port and very graciously apologized. I made a lunch reservation and took a client to Perbacco that week and was warmly greeted by the owner. We were also treated to a complimentary and delicious appetizer! The magic is back!
Great food and great service. •_Darius the bartender was great, fast and remembered my drinks.

Came here because I was craving some noodle soup on a slightly chilly SF night. I was seated right away, which would not have been the case for its neighbour San Tung lol. I decided on the Bun rieu because I wanted to try something new.- Bun rieu: although this bowl looked like fire, it wasn't spicy at all. The deep red colour looked a tad unnatural, but at least the soup didn't taste as artificial as it looked haha. The noodles were alright and there were tomatoes (I think?) soaked in the soup. The ground meat-kind-of-balls were heavily seasoned as well. Something was a bit off about the soup though, there was some weird flavour. Not sure what it was and can't really describe it, but it left a strange after taste.I wasn't so satisfied with the Bun rieu. I'm glad I tried it, to try something new, but other than that, I'm not sure I'll come back again soon.

Of all the food places we visited in SF, HRD was hands down my absolute favorite place to eat. This place takes Asian fusion to a whole new level, with its creative dishes and unique flavors!The first few times we tried to come here early for on in our trip, the place was closed earlier than we expected, so be sure to check the times in advance! We got there about an hour and a half before closing and the place was jam packed! It's a small place with a long table in the middle with benches, a few stand alone tables in the back, and a few seats by the front window. We were lucky to snag a table in the back. The menu is absolutely amazing, and I love how they fuse together so many different dishes. We settled on the smothered burrito and the spicy pork philly cheese-steak. The smothered burrito was out of this world, lemme tell ya! I loved the Japanese curry that was poured over it, and it went amazingly with the kimchi, crispy chicken, and spicy rice in the burrito! I was full about halfway through the burrito but I pushed myself to consume the whole thing--it was just too tasty to stop eating! My boyfriend has the spicy pork cheese-steak, and halfway through my own meal I started stealing bites of his because it was so good! What a kickass twist to an America classic! We left with happy hearts and bulging tummies, and surprisingly full wallets! It's not too expensive of a dinner meal, and for the quality and taste, I would pay way more than what I did to have it again!

Clean, slightly upscale, and worth the wait.Hong Kong Lounge 2 is on the pricey side, but it's one of the nicer spots around to go for a sit down dim sum meal where cart ladies aren't clogging up the floor. •_The shu mai and dumplings are about average, but the pork buns really shine here. •_Our hero even got a head start in ordering while he was waiting by grabbing an ordering sheet and pencil from the staff while waiting for his table. •_If anyone in your party can arrive early, just sign up the the wait list immediately on the weekend because it takes quite some time to get seated here.PROS:- All the food is made to order here.- White table cloths and clean interior.- Lots of parking around (relative to other areas in SF).CONS:- 20-30% pricier than other dim sum joints around.- Up to an hour long wait for lunch on the weekend.

Woof. What an amazing experience here at Zuni Cafe. Sure, the roasted chicken gets a lot of attention, but folks, the burger is the real deal. That's really all you need to know, but if you want to know why? Read on.Star 1: How was the service and atmosphere?Excellent. While the 1600 block of Market Street wouldn't be considered by hardly anyone as 'upscale', you forget about all that the moment you walk in the door at Zuni. Hostesses and Servers dressed to the nines compliments a unique multi-room seating arrangement that's brought together by a kitchen that's wide open. It's great. Star Granted.Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?My only gripe here is the cost. Yes, at Zuni you pay for the atmosphere and an excellent product, but at the end of the day that premium can only go so far. For a quality, freshly made burger? I put that cap right at $15.00, and thanks to an unusual 4% surcharge that's on top of menu prices, my burger was $16.25:yelp.com/user_local_phot_Ü_If it came with fries? Fine, but it didn't, and I can't quite justify that price for just a burger. No Star Granted.Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?Marvelous on all fronts. Let's start with the bun shall we? WOW. I'll say it, off the top of my head, this was the best burger bun I've had. ever. Fresh bread with a tinge of salt and garlic butter, I could have eaten it sans burger and called it a meal. I didn't, and that's because the burger patty was tip top notch. Freshly ground, cooked to perfection and full of flavor, this patty proved that Zuni knows that a good burger is only as good as it's patty. The topping were almost forgotten purely due to the majesty of the burger/patty combo, but the onions and pickles proved a nice touch. Well done Zuni, well done indeed. Dual Stars Granted.Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?Between chicken of citywide fame and a burger that had me reeling, Zuni Cafe blew me away, and I could easily eat there daily if I could afford it. Star Granted.

What's Wong with wongs salad at a Mexican fusion pad with crab cakes?NothingThough the service is a number and drop off.the food here is excellent though.crowded and often forced to sit at a bench with strangers and claustrophobic food feed.More of a night club restaurant feel that I don't really care for clearly geared for people feed.But heck you are here for the fres right?Fish taco fried with beer steak and shrimpAll full of flavor and packed heavy within a small form factor.Crab cakes (for a taco joint?) is fab huge and thick with a compliment slaw to offset the crab cakes. •_Awesome!Best ahi and tilapia beer battered fish taco in my life!Don't come during lunch hour as this gas lines out the door. •_Be smart and avoid the long lines at noon5 stars for foodDock 1 for atmosphere and shoulder to shoulder crowd.

Don't forget Grandpa.We won't. Almost a year after his passing my sister and I were here to celebrate life. Specifically Grandma's birthday. The missing fourth was not far from our minds.So it's no surprise the highlight was spaghetti with Grandpa George's sausage and caramelized onions. Rich and delicious. Small portion of this indulgent dish was perfect.Turkey meatballs with garlic bread was also outstanding if soaked in butter. Didn't dare tell Grandma the meatballs weren't meat. She was too busy with the garlic bread. Us too.Pasta blanket was unique (crabmeat and petrale sole covered with pasta) but way too buttery. We ordered a full size and could have done with half that.Cold pasta topped with fresh fish appetizer was another original. Description was more appealing than the end product which was just OK.Butterfish with leeks main was a similar story as the above. Too much butter and not enough of a side to complement the fish. Just barely worth the $25.Complimentary amuse-bouche of some egg and cheese combo was a nice welcome. Bottle of Argentinian Malbec was a reasonable $34 and kept us going all night.Service was friendly but a bit spotty. There were multiple servers and it was hard develop rapport with any of them. Quite a lag between finishing and getting our check.Cable car rolling by is always a nice touch.Judging from the overall rating and packed crowd in a very cozy space my three stars are the exception not the rule. Wanted to love. Just liked.Enjoy the standout dishes. Be sure to enjoy them with standout company.

Yelpsters you've done it again-Another fine eatery in a land i'm a stranger to. •_I'll wrap it up short and sweet-this place has fabulous food and quick friendly service. The tea! •_Oh the tea! •_Hibiscus I think. Hot leaf tea. I could have left after the tea and been happy but no; I stayed for the hot
Good food, not too over price for the area. Chiken ravioli with mushrooms and sundry tomatoes sauce was reallyyyy good!!! Service so so....

Obama I trusted you!! I came to this dim sum place because I saw pictures that Obama went to it. So, I was like ight, if Obama went then it is pretty decent. I don't think I ever been so wrong. This place was disgusting. Worst dim sum I have had in my life. When I walked in the restaurant it had a horrible smell, kind of like an old sewage. I gave it the benefit of the doubt and sat through it. I thought it was the typical dim sum place where they push a cart around, but nope. You put in a order and they bring it out. So, I am like huh, this dim sum is about to be the freshest, but boy have I ever been so wrong. The chicken feet tasted like the chicken just got done running around and was soggy too. Everything tasted old and bad. We ordered fried pork bun, tripe, tofu roll, shrimp roll (was so bad, so fishy) and a few more. Worst decision to come here. Never again.

Good Italian food that a gluten intolerant good-deal-loving girl can enjoy. And if you want to eat Italian food and are allergic to wheat like me? Two words: Northern Italy. Northern Italy is the home of seafood, polenta and the non-breaded, meals NOT engorged with pasta. Thank goodness. This is my favorite Italian restaurant in the bay area. I read the yelp reviews after I had been coming here for years. It makes me happy to see that this place is loved by the community. The little old lady that I strive to grow up to be is fiercely fond of an early bird special and or a coupon. These are the things that really get me hot if you know what I mean. Somehow it has always worked out for me to get a table without a reservation. My friends and I were once poured a glass of red for the while we ducked in to escape the rain. Thank you that. Italian is hard to enjoy for those of us who are allergic to wheat but this place caters to Northern Italian cooking. It is not just about the pasta but red meat, seafood and phenomenal risotto when truffles are in season. OH. MY. God. My favorite thing on the menu is the Caesar salad with fresh crab. This is no Hershey's kiss sized crab portion but rather a lemon sized amount of protein for your starter salad. Belissimo. There are a few restaurants on this fun funky block that will gain my commerce but this is my favorite of the Italians in the city.

Super friendly waitress. The food came out within minutes. Super small place. Watched the cook hand pull the noodles as we waited for our table. Not a bad way to wait.Authentic chinese food. Ordered the master greens noodle soup, green onion pancake, and beef rolled pancake. The noodle soup and the green onion pancake tastes like something my mom would whip up quickly at home. The beef rolled pancake just tasted like a green onion pancake slathered with oyster sauce with slices of beef on top. No wow factor for me. :(Not worth the hype.

I don't often find myself in this part of town but now I know where to come and eat. I brought my folks here for my graduation dinner. We were seated promptly, the staff and service was stellar, which I have come to expect from all fine SF dining institutions. Unfortunately their menu changes regularly and when I booked the reservation there were a plethora of vegetarian entree options. When we arrived this was not the case. They managed to hold the beef on the sugo but I feel like they screwed the pooch a little by not offering a non-pizza veggie option. But I digress. The two salads went over well with the family, as did the wine. I had the Funghi pizza and man, oh man, it was probably one of the best mushroom-topped things I have ever munched on that didn't involved giggle fits thirty minutes later. We also split the hen gnocchi, which was neon green and not very noteworthy, although the shredded hen was most excellent. For desert some goat, cow, and goat-cow cheese along with raw honey and pickled cherries (which taste like they sound- gross) and a few cups of blue bottle french pressed at the table. All in all it was grand.

This place is pricy, but worth every penny. I had been here a couple of years ago and had told my husband that I really wanted him to try it. We don't live in the city but I work here. So finding an opportunity where we were both in SF was hard. When we saw that there was a Groupon out for them, we found it to be the perfect excuse. We came with our daughter and really took advantage of the fact that we don't come out often by ordering everything we could in hopes to experience as much of the menu as possible. It was truly fantastic and my husband loved it as much as I thought he would. Parking is challenging as it is in most of the city. I was reminding of why we did not have a car when we did live here. The service was great and the ambiance was lively. It was a really nice dining experience overall.

Definite hole in the wall place but so worth it. The food was excellent! Tortilla chips were a little crunchier than I would have liked but still delicious. Guacamole was perfect. Crunchy fish taco was amazing! Huge portions. House margarita was really great too. Great people watching!

Loved my first visit to Beretta. •_It's a place I've been wanting to go for quite a while, and I'm so glad I finally made it. •_The highlight for our group was the walnut bread with burrata and mushroom truffle honey; it was seriously one of the best things I've ever tasted. The rest of the food was great as well, don't get me wrong, but this one item was truly spectacular. •_Service was good, though on the slow side, as the place was packed to the gills. •_Overall a definite 5/5.

Yummy yummy nommy pasta. The linguine alla vongole and tortellini with pesto are amazing. Always cooked perfectly al dente. Skip the appetizers - none are outstanding.Decent wine list as well, by the glass and bottle. Can't wait to try the pizzas next time I visit, they've smelled amazingly!

Fairly clean and spacious restaurant where the majority of patrons are mexican and suggested by our friend of the same team.Very inexpensive compared to other restaurants.Good for post drunken dolores park beach blanket assaults.

Delicious true Italian fare. From the moment you walk in you're family. Waiters are dancing, clapping and having a good time. No pepperoni, no spaghetti and meatballs. Italian pizza sans tomato sauce with prosciutto, shaved Parmesan and arugula. Meat stuffed in noodles with a creamy sauce, squid ink pasta with seafood, NY steak with tomatoes, arugula, shaved mozzarella and potatoes, salad with super light dressing...Had to wait despite reservations. Had to wait after sitting. But that's Italian in itself. Make it an event, not just another meal. •_Go easy on the bread and save room... Three of us had 2 salads, 3 entrees and a pizza.

Hadn't been too Dragon Well since the days when Chinese food was in my dog house, and so, along with all other Chinese joints, I hated it.Things have changed somewhat...Stopped in yesterday with a couple of friends and I can say that for 10 bucks a pop you can have a non-greasy plate of freshly prepared, nice Chinese food. And who doesn't love that?

I have never written a bad review. Never reslly felt a need. Just now i had one of the most disappointing experiences in a restaurant in the city. The people behind me and my mom in line were seated first. •_I watched as people that were seated after us were tended to with water and chips while had not even been offered that. I sat on my hands, done perusing the menu. Waited 10 more minutes before our server sauntered over.

I remember coming to Taiwan Restaurant when I was just a kid. This would be one of the few places my parents would go to have chinese fried donut with warm sweet soybean milk. This was my chinese equivalent of a McDonald's happy meal.Years later... I finally made my return visit to Taiwan Restaurant with a group of my co-workers. Of course I ordered my chinese happy meal. To my amazement some of my co-workers... some who are chinese did not know how to eat this!So... this is how you eat a chinese fried donut with a bowl of warm sweet bean milk. The soybean milk should come without sugar. So, add sugar and mix till you find your perfect sweetness. Next, take a piece of donut and dip into the bean milk. Get it soaked and eat! Easy peasy... japanesey. Or you can toss in a couple of pieces of donut into your bowl and eat it like cereal.As for the rest of the menu... some winners include the chicken wings, Taiwan Seafood Rice and Dry-Braised Green Beans.The dishes may be a little on the salty side but most of the sauces that come with the dishes are tasty.Prices are cheap... $10 bucks for a big lunch... good deal!

Made a day trip to SF, up from Orange County. •_Walked from SoMa out here, which is always an enjoyable thing but particularly on a spectacular sunny day. •_Great views of Alcatraz, Transam etc. nearby.I came in just as they opened for the evening and was able to chat with the team about their history and different food items and wines. •_The food was simply stupendous, with the second best salad I've ever had (Baonecci with pears). Bread like nothing we get in OC (eat it fast while it is still fresh and hot). Truffle salami pizza, which I had them spice up slightly. •_Wow, great stuff. •_And then a perfect canolo. I couldn't send a pic of that to my wife after several others; she would have hated me since she was having a hot dog for dinner. •_Will be suire to bring her here when back.I watched as the place filled mostly with locals, and then, highly satisfied, I caught a some views as the sun settled and headed back to the OC.

Reasonable dim sum, but probably not worth driving through the city if you're not close.Arrived at 2, close enough to the end of service that once we got our number, got seated and had a server, it was last call and we were sort of rushed through with little guidance and a lot of 86s. Also seemed much more interested in us ordering off the menu vs just picking things off a cart. So, a bit harder to get what we wanted. Liked the steamed pork buns and dumplings, pot stickers and even ventured the stuffed eggplant (bland) and crab congee (how are you supposed to get that crab out? Weird..). Soy chicken was a bit dry. Overall, everything was fine, but not extraordinary and would do Yank Sing next time.

I have been to Erics two times. •_Two times for dinner and the other for lunch. •_I experienced inconsistent service. •_Sometime the woman wait staff (she was pregnant when I went) was abrupt and not very friendly (that was one dinner experience). •_Luckily we had reservations so we did not have to wait long. •_There seems to be a lot of repeat customers there. •_ •_I won't go back there for dinner. •_It is way to crowded since the space is small and the tables are close together. •_One lady was on her phone right next to us eating alone but chatting incessantly on the phone. •_Howe irritating!!!I do like he food. •_ •_I like the Walnut Prawns. •_Oh, my if you want to add an extra 600 calories, then this is the dish to get. •_The prawns were large, and the sauce was just the right amount of sweet to compliment the toasted walnuts. •_At lunch I had the Wonton Soup which was excellent. •_I was sick and really needed some hot soup. •_Some of the best I have tasted.The place is small so please make dinner •_reservations. •_ However, the food can be inconsistent and the service for dinner can be a bit dicey. •_I recommend an early lunch there in lieu of dinner. •_You can get a good seat if you get there before the lunch folks come in at 12:00.

As a Singaporean I can honestly say this restaurant has always served pretty good food. However the managers and waitresses has been so terrible, that they have single handedly kept me at bay. Today was different, a new waitress named "Qiong Mei Lin" has single raised the bar and the quality one would expect from a restaurant of this caliber. Thank you, Qiong Mei Lin for the awesome service. We'll be back here more often, as long as you work here.

Is is 1: 15pm, have not gotten into the restaurant yet, it is a rainy day and I come all wet. The guy CAMERON downstairs tells me he can not let me in because our reservation is at 1 30, I tell him I understand but If he can let me in the restaurant because I am getting wet. We start a discussion, I tell him "I am getting wet, can you let me in and wait in the restaurant". He answers "no I can't until five minutes before, you should get an umbrella to not get wet". Hope the food and attention upstairs is better...

Quick bartenders. Good and reliable food. Old school in the best ways.If you're visiting and want a good ol' North Beach experience this should be at least one of your stops, if only for a drink at the bar.

Yay for expensive vegan mexican food.I'll have to admit, vegan mexican food is pretty damn good. Although a bit a skeptical beforehand, I am now a convert. Overall, my friends and I definitely did not miss the meat nor the dairy.Gracias madre has a wide assortment of entrees and main dishes that utilizes the combination of beans, greatly marinaded and seasoned veggies, and protein (tempeh, tofu etc) to satisfied your mexican food craving. All veggies were seasoned and flavored perfectly. Though on the pricier side ($15+) per dish, the portions are huge and able to satiate your hunger.I would recommend almost any of the items on the menu and would recommend having the guacamole to share. They're also very accommodating with substitutions. •_Overall a great choice for those with dietary restrictions and carnivores alike. The horchata...i would skip though. go for the real deal at a mom and pop shop next door.

This is the third time I have been to this location. They have embarrassingly bad service, but what can u expect from a place like Olive Garden. The only thing worth coming here for is the soup, breadsticks and complimentary chocolates at the end.
Food is good, a bit pricey.Nick's way tacos are awesome. One is enough for most, two is enough for me. The salsas on the table are pretty good, too.

This is probably my 5th time at SPQR (not easy to get in).I have to say that it keeps getting better.Last night was the best yet.We had the warm corn salad which was spot on.The triple mushroom and chicken wings had great umami flavor and the wings were perfect.The rabbit in ham dish with figs was super complex in flavor and was one of the more unique and flavorable dishes I have had in recent months.The pork tagliatelle was a solid dish, but the others definitely offered more in terms of depth of flavor.Finally, dessert. •_I would be back there right now if I could to have them again. •_Well worth trying the blueberry pie or the triple chocolate and peanut.

This place is pretty solid, we came here for a quick bite, I initially wanted to go to taqueria Cancun however we didn't feel like walking an extra .2 of a mile.We got the burrito special and guacamole with chips. •_The burrito special was pretty tasty, we got carne asada for our choice of meat, it got pretty close to el farolito standards but not quite there. •_The chips and guacamole were a pretty hefty portion, however it felt as if it lacked flavor, it was still good though.This place is pretty good, I'd definitely come back for a burrito, if you can make it to el farolito that's still my top pick.

Tasty food! Worth the wait? •_ That's debatable. •_ •_They only have 38 seats inside so there is a constant wait time. •_ We waited quite a long time and felt like the food was a little hyped up and maybe not really worth the wait time. •_ But it was good none the less.

They have lots of seating to dine in and great food so i take it to go. When i'm feeling sick the caldo de res does the trick. tacos are easy to order, fast and so good. meat is always moist and full of flavor. one of my favorites in the city!

If you're not looking for this place, you will never find it. It's a charming little hole in the wall, complete with swinging overhead lights as if a subway car was right above you, although it's quiet. Seating is a small bar that faces an open kitchen, where they cook everything fresh. The people that work there are courteous and sweet. I got the garlic house noodles. They were fabulous. Husband got the black bean tofu, which was very good but I like what I got more. We also got the fresh spring rolls with peanut sauce. Yum. Nothing was too filling. Perfect for lunch. And the prices were LOW. Would definitely go back.

Fast and tasty. •_Love the al pastor. •_Portions are very generous and prices are fair. •_Regular burrito is the same size as the super, just w/ out sour cream cheese and guac. •_They don't seem to charge more of you ask them to add guac to a regular.

Decided I wanted crab cakes on a Tuesday night - walked in and sat at the bar since I was alone. Service was outstanding and everyone I came into contact with was friendly. Crab cakes were delicious. Highly recommended!

I visited this restaurant on 19 June 2012 while on vacation in San Francisco.After reading other reviewers of Taco Bar, I have to wonder if we ate at the same restaurant.Overall, the food is very good. I had two of the pulled pork tacos, which were a special the day I was there. The tacos were on your standard size corn tortilla, like you would find in any local supermarket. Another reviewer mentioned that the tortillas were three inches, mine clearly were not. The pork, which was topped by a small amount of citrus marinated onions, •_was tender, tasty, plentiful and clearly of excellent quality. It was not something that you would see in a cheaper taco and wonder what part of the pig it came from. Each taco was $3.25, and in my opinion worth it. After I was finished eating a a man that I think was the chef came to my table. He was very friendly and recommended the coconut flan. It was as good as he said it would be. It was a denser flan, not jello-like in consistency, and very good. Other reviewers mentioned the small portions that one gets at the Taco Bar. After scoping out what the other patrons were eating and seeing the size of my tacos and flan, I have to wonder again if we were eating at the same restaurant.Another reviewer mentioned that this place is "deceptive". I didn't find it so, but if you are doubtful about this place just check out a menu and look around at what others are eating. When I was there the place was very crowded and busy, a deceptive place wouldn't have such a crowd I would think.As for the price, I believe it was fair, given the quality of the food and the quick and friendly service. I found the food at Taco Bar food to be authentic. I come from Los Angeles and have a good idea as to what good Mexican food is thanks to my Mexican friends, colleagues and students. This place is worth your time and cash, check it out, you won't be sorry.

I've been coming here for years and have finally had enough. This place has gone downhill!!! The food lacks so much flavor and isn't worth the price and the service is just as bad. The workers here make it so damn obvious that they hate their job like I'm not here to deal with your shitty attitude man I just want something decent to eat here. Pretty sad considering I actually enjoyed eating here before, but never again

I keep trying Mijita and I want to like it. But I just can't. •_The food doesn't have any flavor. Spent over $9.00 on a "bowl" of tortilla soup....and it was more like a cup. Which frankly was fine because it was so boring I used about a quarter bottle of hot sauce just to give it flavor.

My love affair with Chinese broccoli began here 16 years ago...Glad to see that this place is still one of the best! •_I enjoyed being reintroduced to abalone today...No lunch specials, white folks! •_Just rice plates...
Fantastic food

We came to visit San Francisco for memorial weekend as a gift to my girlfriend and brothers, we use to live here and enjoyed all the activities and food culture here but other than wanting to be in the city and visit pier 39 we stumbled upon Mama's on Washington square. And just like everyone says....expect a wait. It's not one of those waits were you get in and it wasn't great, but a wait where you get there, eat, then realize the wait was well worth. I had the French toast cinnamon swirl and that was complimented with some nice fruits on top, all I can say is this was by far a good highlight for our trip back home.

Their burritos aren't really good. They make it really fast though! I don't think this place is authentic enough for me. Not enough flavor, a bit bland, seems a bit Americanized? so to speak.
